title: coronavirus brooklyn social distancing spots domino park nyc
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Domino Park unveils painted circles in its turf for residents to sit in&nbspA Brooklyn park has debuted “human parking spots” painted onto the grass to encourage social distancing for visitors. Domino Park, a six-acre park located off the East River in Williamsburg, has been covered with white circles meant to encourage social distancing in the era of Covid-19. A video shared online showed residents lounging in the circles, which are about six feet in diameter and spaced away from other circles to remind residents to not interact with others. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSeven charts that show the true scale of the UK coronavirus outbreak‘They can blame it for everything’: What coronavirus means for BrexitThe Americans who think that coronavirus is a hoaxDo you need a face mask and where can you buy one?UK lockdown: Can I see my family and friends under new rules?“They’ve made little round human parking spots in Domino Park in Brooklyn,” wrote Jennifer 8. Lee in the caption to her video. Three months ago the idea of positioning oneself in a painted circle to lounge outside would be a bizarre concept. But now most residents have embraced the park’s guidelines and followed social distancing measures by only sitting in the circles when on the turf.“If you were to take video footage from the world today and show it to someone from 2019, they would think it was from some near-future Hollywood dystopian television show instead of real life,” Ms Lee said. Pictures taken on Monday also showed a majority of residents using the circles and wearing masks when at Domino Park. The public park is owned by a private company and not operated by New York City. Mayor Bill de Blasio and other government officials have collaborated with the NYPD to encourage residents to practice coronavirus protective measures when outdoors, such as passing out masks at parks. Signs also popped up at a number of parks and locations around the city to remind people to stay apart from others when out. Last week the mayor said there would be limits to capacity of parks like Domino Park, Sheep Meadow in Central Park, and piers 45 and 46 in Manhattan’s Hudson River Park over the weekend. But it was not clear if or how these capacity limits were enforced. No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: first photo space hubble telescope image nasa
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Hubble may keep&nbspfunctioning until 2030 or 2040 but its successor scheduled for launch in March 2021While the world has become accustomed to the breathtaking images beamed back from the Hubble Space Telescope, the first image it sent, exactly 30 years ago, is less inspiring, but was extremely important.On 20 May, 1990, Hubble sent back a blurry, black and white image of the binary star HD96755 from its wide field camera. NASA released the image alongside one of the same star, taken from the Las Campanas Observatory in Chile’s Atacama Desert to compare an image from space with one from the earth.The difference in resolution was plain to see, but it still appeared unfocussed. The press and the public were underwhelmed. They had been promised a full colour panorama of galaxies showing the workings of the universe. The telescope had cost $2.5bn and was only providing marginally better pictures.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesEngineers explained that this was part of the calibration process, known as a first light test, to ensure that the optical systems worked. As they calibrated the telescope the quality of the images would improve.Nasa makes landmark announcement about plan to return to the moonHubble Space Telescope breaks in middle of US government shutdownHubble Space Telescope in serious trouble, Nasa saysHubble discovers signs of water on Earth-sized planetsBehind the 2.4m (7.9 feet) wide primary mirror of the telescope’s optical system were 24 pressure pads to make adjustments and correct for any launch damage. However, no matter what the engineers did, nothing appeared to work, and the promised resolution proved elusive.Slowly, after a month of trying, NASA admitted defeat and confirmed that the mirror had a manufacturing flaw and could not be adjusted remotely to compensate for the error. It was not until December 1993, three and a half years later, that the crew of the space shuttle Columbia were able to transport new optical parts to correct the flaw, giving the telescope super sharp resolution and the ability to beam back awe-inspiring photos.As replacing the mirror in orbit was close to impossible, a new optical component, the Corrective Optics Space Telescope Axial Replacement (COSTAR) system, was added that effectively acted as corrective spectacles.Four other servicing missions and upgrades were carried out from 1997 onwards, and COSTAR was removed and returned to earth in 2009 once all the original instruments had been replaced with their own corrections built-in. The telescope may now keep functioning until 2030 or 2040, but nevertheless, its successor, the James Webb Telescope, is scheduled for launch in March 2021.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Former Chicago Bulls star Michael Jordan discussed how his father’s death influenced his decision to retire in 1993NBA star Michael Jordan has addressed rumours concerning his retirement from professional basketball in 1993 during the latest episode of ‘The Last Dance’.On Sunday night, Mr Jordan denied that he had been suspended from the NBA almost 27 years ago because of gambling habits.At the time, some commentators suggested that the then Chicago Bulls star had ended his basketball career because of his behaviour, or that he had been secretly suspended by the league. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut now the 57-year-old has said that his decision to retire at the end of the 1993-94 NBA season was due to the death of his father. title: cyclone amphan india update odisha bangladesh refugee camp
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Storm has begun dumping rain along coastlines where up to 2.5 million people are being moved to safetyCyclone Amphan has begun battering the coastlines of India and Bangladesh with heavy rains and strong winds, with officials scrambling to evacuate as many people as possible before it makes landfall later today.The storm is the most powerful ever recorded in the Bay of Bengal according to meteorologists, sustaining windspeeds of up to 270kph (167mph), and comes at a time when local emergency infrastructure is already stretched to breaking point by the coronavirus pandemic.The Indian government says Amphan is likely to make landfall near the border between Bangladesh and the Indian state of West Bengal at about 5.30pm local time (1pm BST), at which point it will have diminished to a Very Severe Cyclonic Storm with winds gusting to 180kph (112mph).Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBangladesh officials said they were attempting to evacuate 2.2 million people from coastal areas. West Bengal is evacuating 200,000, and the neighbouring state of Odisha said it had moved 100,000 people to shelters.Videos posted on social media showed heavy rainfall along the coast and trees whipping back in the wind. Earlier posts showed people carrying belongings - and wearing face masks to protect themselves from Covid-19 - heading to storm shelters.Seven charts that show the true scale of the UK coronavirus outbreak‘They can blame it for everything’: What coronavirus means for BrexitThe Americans who think that coronavirus is a hoaxDo you need a face mask and where can you buy one?UK lockdown: Can I see my family and friends under new rules?Between them, India and Bangladesh have more than 130,000 confirmed coronavirus cases, and there are concerns that the storm will put additional strain on medical and emergency services and potentially boost the virus's spread.Dr Saleemul Haq from the Independent University of Bangladesh said that while Bangladesh has a strong network of cyclone warning systems and shelters, it will be almost impossible for the evacuated population to practise social distancing in such conditions.Charities are particularly concerned for the fate of the sprawling, densely populated Rohingya refugee camps at Cox's Bazar in Bangladesh, the largest camp of its kind in the world housing almost a million refugees.Cyclone Amphan is a crisis on top of a crisis, said Pankaj Anand, Oxfam India's humanitarian response director. Many of the cyclone evacuation shelters are already being used as coronavirus quarantine centres or housing migrants who have returned to their coastal communities because of lockdown. People are worried there won’t be enough space in the shelters and that they might catch coronavirus in them.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus conspiracy theory australia bank note covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.An Australian bank note is the latest target of conspiracy theorists who do not believe the threat from coronavirus is real.In the bottom right-hand corner of the $10 note sits a spiky design superficially reminiscent of the Covid-19 virus particle with which the world is now familiar.A new conspiracy claim apparently suggests it may represent “proof” the global Covid-19 pandemic is an elaborate hoax, hidden in the notes first released in 2017. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAccording to Australian news website News.au, a post on a popular local anti-coronavirus Facebook group includes a photo of a design on the note with the caption: “The new $10 Australian note complete with coronavirus symbols. You can’t make this up! #areyouawakeyet.”Seven charts that show the true scale of the UK coronavirus outbreak‘They can blame it for everything’: What coronavirus means for BrexitThe Americans who think that coronavirus is a hoaxDo you need a face mask and where can you buy one?UK lockdown: Can I see my family and friends under new rules?Reportedly, the group, which has organised small protests in Sydney and Melbourne, believe the pandemic is an orchestrated effort by billionaires and governments to force vaccinations on the general population.Supporters of the group have reportedly pointed to a bogus video titled “Plandemic” which purports to provide evidence for a host of conspiracy theories loosely tied to the Covid-19 outbreak. These include a claim from Judy Mikovits, an anti-vaccine activist, who states that wearing masks somehow activates the disease within people. She doesn’t provide any evidence for this spurious assertion and criticises orders to stay away from beaches. The entire video has been debunked. The movement has also incorporated other baseless beliefs, including that 5G mobile antennas are dangerous to human health and are somehow related to coronavirus. All this has also been debunked. The design on the bank note features three spiky circular shapes, which could be said to look a bit like highly magnified viruses.There is, however, a simpler explanation: the design represents the round spiky shape of bramble wattle flowers. The plant, a type of acacia, is native to Australia. Its close relative, the golden wattle, was made the official floral emblem of the country in 1988.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: campsites holiday parks open uk
story: BRITS are all in desperate need of a holiday and an escape from the coronavirus lockdown.And while travelling abroad will be tricky in , there are still plenty of beauty spots in the UK to go camping in the near future.Holidays away from the UK are highly unlikely over the next few months as Britain continues to fight the coronavirus pandemic.But in July, campsites could be open across the country, gting hope to Brits eyeing a getaway.Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey told Sky on Tuesday, May : Having come from Suffolk down to London, I know there are a lot of campsites that are very keen for people to come.Some of this is being carefully considered, recognising that we have reduced outdoor transmission risk, that things like camping may well become suitable.Ms Coffey went on to say that later this year, potentially in July could see them open, as long as infection rates continued to decrease.Yet, English caravan sites are hoping to reopen sooner, as they target June - putting them in line with Wales.Government advisors are looking into treating outdoor campsites dferently to hotels and other hospitality venues due to the face that they are outdoors.During a recent press briefing, deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van-Tam said it is a “biological truism” that being outdoors is safer than being in an enclosed space with people potentially carrying the virus.He stressed the complex dangers of reopening campsites too soon but implied that the date could be revised after some careful thoughtHe added: “Of course that will need some careful thinking about because sharing a tent is a small enclosed space or can be a small enclosed space with generally poor conditions of ventilation and I guess it depends who you are sharing it with.This title: rich kind joe wicks inspiring mum
story: If he wasn’t already a household name before this began, Joe, with his spontaneous and generous offer of a daily free PE class, has certainly become one now.A whopping million people tuned in during the first week. He has stuck to his promise and shown up every day, despite having to have surgery on his wrist and being in evident pain at times.Not only that, but he is donating the revenue from advertising on the show to the NHS. He embodies the perfect combination of qualities required to be a good business person: Do all you can, give something back and be ethical.In the past six weeks he has made more than £.million as new fans snapped up his -Day Plan well-being programme from his Body Coach site.But I really don’t think this was about making more money or becoming more famous.Bear in mind that Joe, who is only , has already made millions following the success of his cookbook and his online fitness classes.He really didn’t need to make more money or be more famous.I honestly believe he just wants children everywhere to experience the joy of fitness.There is a lot to like about Joe. But one thing I love about him is that one of his first le goals was to buy his mum, Raquela, a house. Having grown up on a council estate in Surrey, with Raquela and brothers Nikki and George, Joe always dreamed of being able to spend his earnings on his mum after she supported him in the earliest days of his career.“My mum’s always lived in a council house. We’ve never had mortgages. It wasn’t on the radar for us.“So when I could take that money I earned from that book and say ‘Mum, I’m buying your house. It’s yours’, that was an amazing moment for me.”Joe didn’t have an easy childhood. He has spoken about his father Gary still struggling with heroin addiction. But rather than repeating history, he actively decided to take a dferent path.He found exercise as a coping method. “I used exercise probably as a way to manage my feelings,” he has said.He said: “Because of my dad’s addiction, and the damage I saw it cause, me and Nikki steered clear of it. We weren’t smoking weed. We were training, exercising and playing sport. Along the line, I decided that wasn’t going to be my destiny.”Things in le either crush you or make you the person you were always meant to be. The strength of character it takes to turn your back on the path chosen by your first and most important role model — your dad — is immense.It would be so easy for him to have chosen the same path as his father or use his father’s addiction as an excuse for not making the most of his le.Joe has said he tries not to dwell on his past nor judge his dad. All that matters to him now is being happy and looking forward.The moral of this story is: Put the graft in, keep pushing yourself and never give up.But one of the many likeable things about Joe is how readily he credits Raquela for her role in his success, saying she taught them “right and wrong”, while his dad was “in and out of rehab”.She must be a hell of a woman to have brought up three boys so well. Joe and Nikki work together now, which is testament to the strength of their family ties.Knowing all this about Joe makes it all the more amazing he found his happy ever after when he married his model we Rosie in , and the pair now have two adorable children — Indie who’s  months and four-month-old Marley.It would be easy to resent his success. But how could anyone wish Joe anything other than happiness, given what he has overcome and also his approach to le I’m as keen as the next person for the lockdown to end and for normal le to resume – at least as much as it possibly can.But when I read about the fliers advertising mass gatherings, promising picnics and live music in cities across the UK this weekend, I couldn’t believe my eyes.At least eight events were being organised by anti-vaxxing group UK Freedom Movement, which claims the lockdown is illegal.Its posters headlined “UK Mass Gathering” said: “We say no to the coronavirus bill, no to mandatory vaccines, no to the new normal and no to the unlawful lockdown.”It is also urged people to gather in a major park in the eight locations, including London, Sheffield and Edinburgh, to “bring a picnic, some music and let’s have some fun and say yes to le”.Yes, lockdown measures are extreme and yes, we all want them to relax and for normality to .But what the organisers of this are failing to realise is that you can’t protest or demonstrate against a virus.And while there is so much still left for us to understand about how this particular virus works, to attend a mass gathering in protest seems like a fool’s errand.This event is clearly organised by idiots, for idiots.If only we’d all been quick-witted enough to self-isolate with someone who knows how to do our hair, like Kate Moss, who has been hunkering down with A-lister stylist James Brown.That said, Kate is an absolute beauty and clearly a supermodel, whether she is having a good hair day or a bad one.As luck would have it I am currently living with my mum.She has done a grand job dyeing my roots so far, but I think a blow-dry may be beyond her remit.Luckily, with a pandemic going on, and staff to worry about, I have more important things to think about than my hair.Twitter has been among the first companies to announce that it will not be bringing employees back into the workplacethey would prefer to work from home.And for more and more people, home is likely to be the new workplace – with meetings taking place on screens.The past few weeks have shown us that as long as people have a laptop and wi-fi, many can work from home.For lots of us, being allowed to do so means we save loads of money on travel and hundreds of hours of commuting time, while massively reducing our carbon footprint.And we’ll never have to buy a stale sandwich again.Meanwhile, companies will save a fortune on rent.All in all, this new way of working, for those who can do it, makes sense.Over the past few weeks we have all become much more aware of people’s proximity to us.And yes, with streets that have fewer cars than ever before, no doubt some of us are stepping into the road to avoid another pedestrian who could come within two metres of us.But police have felt the need to issue warnings to pedestrians not to walk into the road to dodge fellow pedestrians because it is dangerous .Seriously, is such a warning really necessary I know we have all been in lockdown for a while but surely we haven’t taken leave of our common sense and will remember to look left and right when we cross the road . . . won’t we It’s now been eight weeks since our Thursday night Clap For Carers began. And looking at this photo of Boris Johnson outside No from Thursday, it’s a good reminder that things are changing all the time.When you compare it to the picture taken of him just days before he was admitted to hospital it really shows the big dference a few weeks make.He looks more or less back to his old self. Also, it’s really cheering to see new mum Carrie looking so well and so happy.We seem to be seeing lots of people in their swim-wear at the moment, with not a. pool in sight!Normally I try to give thanks for my strong and able body rather than worrying too much about what it looks like.But it’s hard not to feel a tad wistful looking at photos of Kimberley Garner, who looks so fit and gorgeous she’d no doubt be awarded swimwear body of the week,such an award existed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: menthol cigarettes uk ban when law effect why
story: Shops have been warned that the EU directive makes it an offence for retailers to sell menthols.The smoking of menthol cigarettes is signicantly more common among newer, younger smokers, says Action on Smoking and Health .Theres a greater risk of progressing to regular smoking and nicotine dependence for those who start on menthols compared to those puffing on plain versions.Young people are more likely to get hooked as menthol makes it easier to inhale the smoke into the lungs by creating a sweeter, milder, or “colder” smoke and by reducing its harshness.These flavoured fags are being banned in the UK under EU laws which still apply during the Brexit transition.The legislation stems from the EU Tobacco Products Directive . This tough rule has been transposed into UK law, and will remain in force after the end of the transition period for leaving the EU comes to an end on December  .Menthol flavoured cigarettes are banned from May .The prohibition extends to outlawing menthol rolling tobacco and skinny cigs, meaning menthol smokers will have to switch - or quit.It also applies to capsule, click on, click and roll, crushball or dual menthol cigarettes, says the Association of Convenience Stores .The UK’s exit from the European Union does not impact the introduction of the menthol ban.Brazil was the first country to prohibit all flavoured tobacco including menthol.Canada imposed a nationwide ban on menthol cigarettes that took effect in October .And in the US, Massachusetts became the first state to ban flavoured tobacco and nicotine vaping products, including menthol cigs.Anti-smoking groups hailed the ban which restricts sale and consumption of flavoured vaping products immediately and does the same for menthol cigarettes starting June , .The American Cancer Society’s Cancer Action Network said: “More than  per cent of teens who have ever used a tobacco product started with a flavoured product, and the tobacco industry knows this.But Spanish smokers are fuming over the menthol fag ban across Europe, slamming the EU for meddling with their social lives, says the Euro Weekly.In , smaller packs of rolling tobacco were banned, as well as  packs of cigarettes.Tobacco products have already been hidden under the counter and stripped of branding.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: get businesses open coronavirus
story: As the chief of the OBR made crystal-clear yesterday, the scarring will be permanent unless society can be ed to some semblance of normality as soon as is safely possible.Which means serious thought must now be given to getting businesses open:that involves masks in workplaces and Perspex separations in cafes and bars, so be it. It might feel strange at first, but we’ll get used to it.Militant unions telling teachers they should refuse to go back to work must also urgently rethink their stance.Reopening schools is obviously essentialwe are to prevent the poorest and most vulnerable children falling behind — new research reveals that better-off children are spending a whopping  per cent more time each day on education than those from poorer homes.But as parents can only go back to work once their kids are in class, it’s also the only way to kickstart the economy.Of course, there will always be an element of risk to getting society up and running again. Even before coronavirus, it would have been impossible for anyone to guarantee the safety of every worker every day.But the Government has stressed it’s “extremely unlikely” a school could be the source of a Covid- outbreak.And given the risks frontliners take every single day, that assurance should be good enough for teaching unions.WE welcome the news that the Government plans to push ahead with legislation to end free movement and replace it with a points-based immigration system before the end of this year.The new system is exactly what Brexit-voting Sun readers wanted: it will let us welcome the brightest and best — including doctors, nurses and carers — to the UK based on what they have to offer, not where they come from.And it’s logical to get it introduced quickly so businesses have time to prepare before the transition period ends.Let’s hope MPs have the sense to back the bill.WE can all sleep a little more soundly in our beds now the Government looks set to hit its target of recruiting , contact-tracers by the end of next week.It’s been obvious for a long time that widespread testing and tracing is the best way to contain the virus: all the countries that have fared best have been doing it from the start.But thanks to dodgy advice from Public Health England, Boris and his ministers gave up on it back in March.What a relief they’ve finally seen the light.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: next uk lockdown update coronavirus
story: Although some restrictions have since been eased following a review, other directives such as the closure of schools and non-essential shops are still subjected to further updates from the government.According to the law which brought about the lockdown, the Government must review restriction measures every three weeks.The last review was on May , with Boris Johnson making changes on May .This means the next review could be held in the week beginning May .The Governments next review is expected to clary the status on a number of restrictions put in place as a result of the coronavirus lockdown.Brits will be expecting to learn whether restrictions will be relaxed and how the country is being led to a level of normality.Among the measures which could be given further clarity after the next review are: Following the Prime Minister, Boris Johnsons speech on the lockdown rules on May , things were slightly eased in England.People are still urged to work from home for the foreseeable future, however those who cannot do so are allowed to travel to worktheir workplaces are open.These include people who work in the food production industry, construction workers and those who partake in scientic research.This rule does not apply to hospitality workers employed in cinemas, pubs and restaurants. They must remain shut until a later date.Public transport must be avoided, according to the new lockdown rules, although reports have shown packed buses and trains in parts of the country.Brits are now allowed to meet people who are not members of their household, providing they follow social distancing guidelines.Funerals are still allowed to go ahead with a limited amount of attendees, of immediate family members.The rules on exercising have also been changed with people now able to take unlimited outdoor exercise.With the approach of summer, people are also now able to go to the park to sunbathe and must follow social distancing measures.The Government announced the lockdown on March .In an unprecedented move, Brits were ordered to stay at home with the exception of key workers, while non-essential shops and facilities such as restaurants, gyms and pubs were instructed to shut.Schools were also closed as a result of the lockdown rules.The restrictions were due to last for three works but were extended following review and advice from ious communities and departments.Lockdown measures are expected to last into June and may go beyond that, following guidelines by the government.Social distancing rules are however, expected to be in place beyond that.Mr Johnson has indicated that he wants the UK to resume near normality by July.He has said this would depend on whether the public abides by the new lockdown rules.Measures are currently being eased in phases with the final steps being the reopening of non-essential businesses.The earliest these final steps will be taken is July , according to the Governments -page action plan for leading the country to a new normal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what current r rate area how track it
story: THE infamous R rate is currently guiding the Governments coronavirus response, as each of the planned phases depend on how infectious Covid- is. The rate has emerged during several Downing Street briefings, with both officials and the Prime Minister.Dferent parts of the UK have a dferent R infection rate - which is used to indicate the speed the virus is spreading.According to experts from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, the East Midlands has the fastest spread of infection with a rate of between . and ..London, which has been the hardest hit in the country has a R rate of . to . — the lowest in the country.Herefordshire, Norfolk, Durham and Cumberland have  times as many cases as Devon, Cornwall and Dorset.While this is dficult to measure, a number of reasons could come into play here, among them the fact the R rate will tend to be higher in places with higher population densities, like large cities such as London.Certain places which saw a large number of coronavirus cases may now also have a large number of people with immunity to the virus, while cities will also tend to have more care homes and hospitals which will affect the numbers.There are also dferences in how people live together, with people usually living in bigger family groups outside the large cities.Similarly, places with higher levels of deprivation and poverty will affect the R rate as well.Public Health England together with researchers at the University of Cambridge are working to regularly nowcast and forecast Covid- infections and deaths. This is real-time tracking of the pandemic, as data accumulate over time, and is an essential component of a public health response to a new outbreak.Click here to see the latest R rate in your area. The so-called R number is now between . and . — it needs to be kept below one.Below R is the important bit because it means the virus will likely peter out.The R rate needs to be below  for the UK to move out of lockdown.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ally ross live dutch eurovision tribute
story: Wimbledon  Couldn’t care less.Glastonbury  I was genuinely thrilled to hear the environment would be getting a break from all those thousands of marauding BBC staffers.But Eurovision  That one stopped me in my tracks with a “say it ain’t so ” when I heard it was cancelled.It’s nearly always my favourite TV event of the year and the BBC’s most entertaining live broadcast by some distance.Disappointment turned to hope, however, when I learned the BBC was going to fill several blank hours with a night of Eurovision programmes.A four-pronged assault,you include Rylan’s A to Z, on BBC, that began badly with a Pointless special and a top  rundown of songs on Eurovision: Come Together, where the only new thing we learned was that Britain’s  entrant, James Newman, looks “a bit Fred West” after two months of lockdown.The night’s success or failure, though, was always going to hinge on a hastily arranged live broadcast from the Netherlands called Eurovision: Europe Shine A Light, in honour of Katrina And The Waves, which had me in the palm of its hand from the moment Graham Norton introduced it as “well meaning”.He did not lie.It was as well meaning as hell, with three very earnest Dutch hosts plus Norton, on his usual voiceover duties, introducing a -second burst of all  entries, followed by the artists’ thoughts and reflections on the global coronavirus pandemic, which were everything and anything you wanted them to be.Some were sweet and to the point, like Azerbaijan’s Efendi: “Stay hellzy!”Others were easy to misinterpret, like Moldova’s Natalia Gordienko: “A penis is wad surrounds you.”And Austria’s Vincent Bueno was just a self-serving berk: “At this time we should listen to a lot of music. Especially my track, Alive.”The music didn’t disappoint, either, ranging all the way from the excellent Icelandic entry, Think Of Things, to knock-kneed techno from some Russian live-wires called Little Big.My personal highlight, though, was the nutty Latvian bird, Samanta Tina, who turned up for her promotional video wearing a PPE mask and squirting a bottle of disinfectant everywhere.If ever it got a bit too “Eurovision”, though, there was a special guest on hand to calm the mood down.Sweden’s Mans Zelmerlow sang Heroes in his back garden , Italy’s Diodato slowly murdered Volare in a CGI amphitheatre and Ireland’s Johnny Logan had either aged quite dramatically or had to be replaced, right at the last second, by Julian Assange on the poignant What’s Another Year.The one constant, though, was Norton, who handled Eurovision’s new socially-distanced, time-delayed, non-competitive format as brilliantly as he did the old one and was in no mood to spare feelings.“Samanta Tina. She’s tried to represent Latvia six times, Lithuania twice and now she’s got through it’s been cancelled. You’d think she’d take the hint, wouldn’t you.”“Serbia’s answer to The Pussycat Dolls, when the question is — name a group that isn’t as good as The Pussycat Dolls ”It was a joy to watch after seeing so many hosts and shows fail spectacularly with “the new normal” and my only real complaint was that there wasn’t enough of him or the event.I wanted a vote as well, of course. But by the time I was ready for Norton to annihilate the regional juries, it was all over.Lesson learned, though. If I ever take this event for granted or complain about the running time again, you have permission to shoot me down in righteous flames.Meantime, stay hellzy.The Real Marigold Hotel, Britt Ekland: “I look in the mirror — it’s OK. I’m not going to scare the children.”Channel  continuity introducing The Last Leg: Locked Down Under: “Two comedy geniuses coming right up here, Aisling Bea and Kevin Bridges.” So, one comedy genius then. And Aisling Bea.BACK in southern India, on BBC’s hugely enjoyable series The Real Marigold Hotel, Duncan Bannatyne has just bottled the eight-hour overnight train journey to Madurai.It could’ve been the heat, it could’ve been the food and a dodgy stomach.Or it could’ve been the fact Britt Ekland is all over him like a cheap sari, no matter how many times the multi-millionaire businessman mentions his “young we”.A woman who will not be denied, Britt needs male validation and constant reassurance.So, during one of the brief moments she wasn’t pestering Duncan to within an inch of his le, Britt visited a vedic astrologer, in downtown Puducherry, and hit him with this loaded question. “Am I going to have work ”Work  Are you ever, Britt. “The sun is in the constellation of Hasta,” apparently.So I’d expect work on your face, work on your eyelids, work on your rear end. A work frenzy, in fact.As for actual employment, though I think we can safely say Venus’s transit is currently “resting’ and her earth signs will be “aspecting”, until the panto equinox. So I’d go with Plan A Duncan.Yet when Miriam Margolyes told The Last Leg she wanted Boris Johnson to die from coronavirus they said nothing.So do you think this is because A Equity’s learned its lesson about rushing to judgment  Or B The thought she’d said something wrong never entered their thick, hypocritical luvvie heads No need to reply.Danny Murphy: “Spurs have always been consistently inconsistent.”Joe Root: “We have to make sure players don’t get ill, or even unwell.”WORST TV show of the lockdown  I’ll hear your pleas on behalf of Have I Got News For You, Gemma Collins: Diva On Lockdown, The Mash Report, The Steph Show and Mo Gilligan, whose All Star Happy Hour on Channel  makes Rob  Romesh look like Abbott  Costello.But they can, I suppose, all use technology as an excuse. Only stupidity and a tin ear for the public mood can explain my own choice for that title.It’s BBC’s credit card roulette series I’ll Get This, which concluded last week with Fleur East, Johnny Vegas, Mike Tindall, John Barnes and Sue Perkins taking part in a series of minor challenges and guessing games, in a roped-off area of a London restaurant, to settle a £ dinner bill.Not the sort of guessing games that might have engaged viewers, like “guess the appearance fee” or “guess how many TV presenters would have to die before Sue got another stab at hosting the Baftas”, but a game of “Guess the weight of the waiter”.A task more suited to the Bullingdon Club, you’d imagine, but this lot prodded him, lted him and generally talked about him like he was invisible.“I can squat it.” “Oh God, he’s big boned.”Having established, beyond reasonable doubt, there was almost nothing the five celebrities wouldn’t do to get on television, it was the response to the next question – “Do you like or dislike being famous ” – that sealed its place in lockdown hell for me.Unanimously they went for the latter, not with any self-awareness or sarcasm, but with a genuine sense of hurt that anyone could think otherwise and former Celebrity Big Brother contestant Sue Perkins apparently speaking for them all when she very solemnly replied: “I love my job, I dislike being famous.”Some job, Sue. Some bloody job.THIS week’s winner is ABC’s Martin Fry and Kate Green MP, as seen in C’s excellent The Truth About Traveller Crime.Sent in by Francis Harvey. Picture research Alfie Snelling.HARDBALL, Ore Oduba: “An Irish stew is traditionally made using which meat ”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The young of what flying mammals are called pups ”Jim: “Seals.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which famous British vet wrote If Only They Could Talk and It Shouldn’t Happen to a Vet ”.Davie Robertson describing a bout of Himalayan altitude sickness on BBC Scotland’s wonderful Return To Real Kashmir FC docu- mentary: “The worst day of my le, and I’ve played at Albion Rovers.” Jeremy Clarkson turning out to be a better Millionaire host than Chris Tarrant.And an -year-old patient called Peter, who was saved from the Holocaust as a small child, winning his battle for le, against all odds, on BBC’s Hospital Special: Fighting Covid- – an astonishing two-part series that was a privilege to watch.THIS Morning’s Phillip Schofield attempting to jump on board Piers Morgan’s Covid outrage bandwagon.The terrying news Shirley Carter and the rest of the EastEnders cast will be “doing their own hair and make-up from now on”, as I’d assumed they already did.White Lines turning out to be just another load of over-hyped Netflix rubbish.And Antiviral Wipe host Charlie Brooker becoming the latest in a long line of TV presenters to exclude men from his list of groups at more risk of dying from coronavirus.Because even though we’re  to  per cent more likely to die than women, in every country, it’s box-ticking political correctness that drives the BBC’s news coverage, not basic compassion and humanity. Despicable really.A He’s taking part in an eating contest on Channel ’s Paul Hollywood Eats Japan B He’s failing his audition for MTV’s Celebrity Ex On The Beach GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teachers unions science re open schools
story: You’d think they would be keener than anyone to heed the science.But when Government experts or even the WHO contradict their desire to keep schools shut, they ignore it.Or they wheel out the BMA — asit represented medical opinion, rather than just being another left-wing trade union.Their latest wheeze, part of an absurd dossier of  demands, is to refuse to mark homework in case members catch Covid from a book.The risk is minuscule . . . nil,they take precautions.Most primary kids the Government wants toon June  get minimal homework anyway.And, as Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jonathan Van-Tam says, they neither catch the disease severely nor pass it on like they do flu.It is impossible to ensure that teachers will be  per cent safe before they— as it is for any worker.There WILL be a statistically tiny threat as long as this disease persists. Le is full of them. This is another.Unions cannot demand an exemption.This protracted shutdown is already doing immense damage to pupils, especially the most disadvantaged.The truth is the unions are capitalising on a mainly middle-class reluctance toto work because many have lost perspective about the real risk.In fairness, that reflects the success of the Government’s “stay home” campaign.But now deaths and infections are falling steadily and the economy is in dire trouble we must sht gear.Publishing daily figures of Covid recoveries will help.Not least because the total will be in the millions, as opposed to the death toll of ,.Awful though that latter figure is, it remains a small fraction of the overall.So does the recent estimate of those now infected: some , in England, of a population of ,,.Only one in  has Covid, in some areas far less.The fact we can now test everyone with symptoms, and have , contact tracers, should drive even those figures down.Teachers, meantime, should ponder whether their unions have lost the plot.WE welcome Prince Charles’s call for anyone currently furloughed to help rescue our farmers by picking vital fruit and veg.We welcome, too, that you’ll get paid on top of your bailout cash. today — and help feed Britain through our worst crisis since the war.IF fruit picking isn’t your bag, you can do your bit for public health just by sunbathing.Lack of vitamin D is linked to the more severe coronavirus bouts.And you can top that up by exposure to sunshine in what looks like being a glorious week.We’ve always said The Sun’s good for you.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: therese coffey blame game wrong advice
story: DWP boss Thérèse Coffey suggested that ministers could only make their decisions on the information they had in front of them at the time.She told Sky News this morning: You can only make judgements based on the advice...I recognise things like testing capacity...If the science was wrong, advice at the time was wrong, I am not surprised people think we made the wrong decisions.She added: “We are getting advice from the scientists. It is for ministers to decide on policy.“We have tried to take, every step of the way, making sure that we listen to the science, understand the science, and make decisions based on that.”But Downing Street has suggested it accepts ministers bear responsibility for the decisions in the coronavirus response.The Prime Minister is hugely grateful for the hard work and expertise of the UKs world-leading scientists, weve been guided by their advice throughout and we continue to do so, the Prime Ministers official spokesman said today.He stressed that it was not solely down to scientic advice.The spokesperson added: Scientists provide advice to the Government, ministers ultimately decide.Her blunt words came after MPs said health chiefs decision to stop mass testing in March changed the outcome of the whole coronavirus crisis.In a damning finding, MPs on the Science and Technology Committee blasted Public Health England chiefs for the unacceptable failure to publish evidence to back up the decision to stop track and tracing.Ministers are now working on getting contact tracing back up and running again, including an NHS app.About , tracers have been hired with the aim to get the system going as soon as possible.In a letter to Boris Johnson the cross-party MPs said that the decision left many, especially in care homes unable to be tested “when the spread of the virus was most rampant.”And care home bosses today furiously lashed out at the Government for failing to focus on them in the start of the pandemic.Professor Martin Green, Chief Executive of Care England, told the Health Select Committee this morning that there WERE cases of people....who were symptomatic discharged into care homes.And he added: We should have been focusing on care homes from the start of this pandemic. The focus was on the NHS and support was withdrawn.He said that testing is improving but some people are still waiting up to ten days for a test.We need regular testing, two to three times a week,we are to really get on top of this, he stressed.A leaked report found today that agency staff spread coronavirus between care homes in the early days of the pandemic. claimed a leaked Public Health England study found workers who transmitted coronavirus across six care homes.In some cases, the agency staff had been brought in to cover for staff who were self-isolating to prevent the vulnerable people they looked after from becoming infected.The paper reported the study was conducted over the Easter weekend in April, but the details were only circulated to care home providers, councils and local directors of public health last week.It comes after Matt Hancock gave out £million of funding last week to stop care home workers going into multiple homes.The workers will be compensated and paid to make sure they dont lose out by stopping some work.More than , care home residents are estimated to have died in England and Wales, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson admitting there had been an appalling epidemic in care homes., official deaths have been recorded from care homes so far - both inside and outside hospital.Nearly four in ten care homes have reported outbreaks, fresh figures revealed yesterday.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain extra bank holiday after lockdown

title: boris relax distance economy
story: Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith claimed Britain needed to slash the distance people must be apart to get the nation back in work.Appearing on BBC Radio ’s Today programme, the prominent backbencher warned unemployment depends on how quickly the economy starts back up again.He said: “We need to get that moving as quick as possible and Ive certainly been arguing that for some weeks now.“Were the only country certainly in Europe that I know of that uses the two-metre rule.“I think when it comes to the hospitality sector, I think we do need to look at it very carefully.“So we do need to look at how they manage that process and give them some flexibility.”Current Government guidance says you must be two metres away from anyone not in your household.The World Health Organisation recommends at least one metre, which is the rule followed in Spain, Italy, Austria, Finland, Sweden and Norway.In Germany, Poland and the Netherlands the distance is . metres, with just the UK, Switzerland and US staying two metres apart.Earlier this month the Government’s chief scientic adviser warned that coronavirus transmission is signicantly higher at one metre apart.Sir Patrick Vallance claimed spending six seconds one metre away carries the same risk as a minute two metres apart.His stark warning comes as the number of people claiming benefits in April soared by  per cent to almost .million due to the coronavirus crisis.With , more people claiming unemployment benefits in April  compared to March, according to the Office for National Statisticstoday.Meanwhile, unemployment figures jumped by , to .million in the three months to March, the ONS said.It takes Britains unemployment rate up to . per cent.The retail, travel and hospitality industries have been particularly hard hit by coronavirus, with job losses and pay cuts being announced and some firms folding altogether.British Airways, for example, has announced that up to , jobs are to be scrapped while Ryanair is axing up to , roles.On the high street, Debenhams has gone into administration, and Cath Kidston, Oasis and Warehouse have shut their doors for good.On a regional basis, Blackpool, Liverpool and Hull have suffered the highest spikes in unemployment from March to April.Meanwhile, this morning former Prime Minister Gordon Brown claimed social distancing and hand washing will not be enough to stop a second wave.He said: Weve lost probably around , to , lives in care homes and not even now are most workers and most care home residents being tested.Weve known about this for more than two months and not even today can we say weve tested all those people who may be at risk.This is a disease where people dont have symptoms even though they are contagious and its been rushing through care homes.Experts are currently preparing to lt restrictions in reverse, possibly re-opening schools first followed by shops and pubs - with the ban on large gatherings last to end.But scientists have warned some measures could stay to prevent coronavirus infections from spiking again.They are considering asking the public to continue voluntary social distancing, such as avoiding visiting relatives and working from home as much as possible.Experts say we might have to change to our way of le indefinitely, at least until a vaccine is developed, but it might be impossible to eradicate the virus.It comes as a furious row broke out today as a minister blamed wrong advice and wrong science for the testing shambles which saw Britain abandon its track and trace policy.DWP boss Thérèse Coffey suggested that ministers could only make their decisions on the information they had in front of them at the time.

title: mansion for sale troy house monmouthshire 33 bedrooms
story: Troy House in Monmouthshire originates from the th century and comes with its own chapel, but the auctioneers have warned it needs “extensive” work to make it habitable.It was originally built for the family of the Duke of Beaufort and comes with six acres set in beautul countryside along with two tennis courts.But after having been previously used as a school and a hostel the , sq ft property has seen better days.Auctioneers Allsop warn: “Presented in poor condition and requiring extensive works of modernisation and refurbishment.”It adds: “The property may afford possible potential for redevelopment and or a number of alternative uses, subject to obtaining all necessary consents.”These photos show just how much work needs doing after years of neglect.The oldest part of the house dates back to the s when it was built by Henry Somerset and is said to have hosted Henry VII for five days in August .The current house was built in the th century.During its more recent history it was owned by an order of French Catholic nuns who used it as a convent and girls’ school.It has also been used as a school for boys.Richard Adamson, Partner and Auctioneer at Allsop said: “Troy House has received a signicant amount of interest with over  enquiries regarding the property, in just over a week of coming to the market.“We have seen a mixed-bag of interest from people who could use the property for multiple uses including as a private home, converting into a boutique hotel and spa or refurbished into luxury apartments, subject to planning.“The property has a committed seller who is happy for the house to be sold at true value - as a result, we anticipate some competitive bidding on auction day.”The property is due to be put up for auction on May  with bidding taking place online due to the coronavirus restrictions.

title: brit cruise liner crew return home stranded sea
story: The workers were stuck on board the vessels for more than two months as the Centre for Disease Controlwouldn’t let them dock in Miami.After almost ten weeks at sea Royal Caribbean Cruises chartered a plane from BA to finally bring  members of staff home.Joyful family members squealed as they rushed to hug them as they came into Arrivals in Heathrow just after pm.One woman burst into tears as she embraced her daughter.The Celebrity cruise staff spoke of their relief to finally be back in the UK after their weeks-long ordealOne member of entertainment staff, who didn’t want to be named, told The Sun: “I’m so happy to be back.“We had our hopes up so many times that we’d get back so I’m so relieved to finally be here.“We had to isolate in our cabins, it got so boring. It was really dficult and we weren’t given a lot of information. “One engineer who worked for both Liberty and Enchantment ships said it was “a long few weeks” on board - and couldn’t wait to get reunited with his family.Celebrity have organised coaches for the cruise staff to get them home as they are from all over the UK.The staff were not tested upon landing at Heathrow but had been given a medical examination and certicate of health in America before boarding the BA flight.Kirstie Mingham, , was at Heathrow collecting a friends son, Sam.She said the crew had been trapped in the cabins for weeks with no information about when they’d get back.She told The Sun: “It’s been a horric experience for them.“Some of them have been in tiny cabins with no windows and no fresh air, only allowed to leave to get food - imagine how you’d feel.“They’ve had no real information or communication for weeks.“Several times they’d been told they’d be able to go home only for the plans to fall through so I can’t even explain now happy I am to see that his plane has landed.A source told The Sun the staff had held several strikes in a bid to be allowed home.They said: “The crew were in great spirits, clapping and cheering on the plane.“They were brought to the plane under the strictest conditions - no mixing with public, bussed straight to the airport and taken straight on to the plane.”One of the happy crew toto British soil blasted Celebrity CEO Lisa Lutoff-Perlo, saying she kept them on board because she didn’t want to pay for the charter flight after the CDC said cruise staff couldn’t get a commercial flight home.A spokeswoman for Royal Caribbean Cruises said: We are pleased to confirm that our UKI crew are being repatriated and land in the UK today.We have already been able to help , of our colleaguessafely home on commercial flights, charter flights and direct sailings to their home countries and thousands more are going home in the coming days.We are working with governments and health authorities around the world on our plans, and we very much appreciate our crews’ patience, understanding and good spirit.Our foremost priority is getting our crew members home safely and we are investing heavily in this massive endeavor. We will not rest until they are home safely.

title: dad pushing toddler balcony swing
story: The heart-stopping video shows the man repeatedly pushing child believed to be his daughter, on the balcony of their Puerto Rico apartment.In the  second clip, the child flies high up into the air and nearly up to the balcony above the apartment.Despite the balcony being on the eighth floor, the toddler doesn’t appear to be secured with any safety equipment.The video was captured by Jonathan Padilla, a journalist for the Mexican Herald, and was widely shared on Reddit.A man swung his underage daughter on the balcony of his apartment during this quarantine,” he said.Those who saw the video slammed the man for risking his childs le.Just because you cannot go to the park does not mean you can risk your childs le, said oneOthers pointed out the dad could have installed the swing inside the flat.All you need is an over the door pull up bar, and this swing could be inside the apartment.Some said the child could easily have slipped off the swing and fallen off the building .They have swings that go on door jams and that you can mount in the door frame. title: rishi sunak severe coronavirus recession
story: CHANCELLOR Rishi Sunak has warned the UK is facing a severe recession, the likes of which the nation has never seen before.He told MPs today the Government would not be able to save every job and there could be a long-term scarring of the British economy.He said: I certainly wont be able to protect every job and every business, were already seeing in the data there will be more hardship to come.Lockdown is having a signicant impact on our economy and we are likely to face a severe recession the likes of which we havent seen .Of course that will have an impact on employment.Mr Sunak said theand depth of that recession will depend on how much longer the nation is forced to stay in economic shutdown to keep coronavirus from ripping through the UK.He said: The question that occupies my mind and long term is more relevant is to what degree of long term scarring is there on the economy as the result of this recession The number of people claiming unemployment benefits has soared to . million, rising by , in April compared to March, and the number of people relying on the Governments furlough and self-employment schemes has hit  million.It was revealed this morning unemployment in the UK had skyrocketed by , to . million in three months to March.She said: “It’s a struggle month on month on my salary, so this has hit me hard.It couldn’t have come at a worse time.”Mr Sunak said: The question iswhat do weto  The jury is out.We are clearly dealing with something unprecedented, so the longer the depth of the recession it is likely the degree of that scarring will be greater.National economic growth slumped by a massive . per cent in just March alone - before the country had even experience a full month in lockdown.The collapse is the largest ever monthly slump on record.The Treasury predicted last week the pandemic will cost the exchequer £billion this year. The Office of Budget Responsibilityhas also warned that the nation will have to borrow £ billion just this year to buoy up the Governments support schemes.Mr Sunak said the cost of both the employee furlough and self employed schemes would cost several tens of billions of pounds by the time those schemes are wound down.Mr Llewellyn, of Darlington, Co Durham, said: “I am due a payment from the Government but it hasn’t arrived yet.It has been horrible not being able to work, it is all I’ve ever known.”The Chancellor announced last week that the furlough scheme - which pays employees  per cent of their pay up to £, a month - would be extended to October.He said today: This is unprecedented action, clearly, I genuinely believe that the situation would be considerably worse long term had we not taken this action.We will have increased debt as a result of this year, but medium term what will matter is what is the size of our economy To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: More local authorities yesterday advised their schools to stay closed on that date, including the first Tory-run council.It also emerged the NEU teaching union boss has threatened to wage a social media campaign against heads who defy their orders.Conservative-controlled Solihull in the West Midlands said yesterday classrooms must be made safe and may not be ready until June .Leeds City Council said a June  reopening would be “impossible” while Sefton Council in Merseyside urged schools to close until June .Calderdale Council in West Yorks said it will defy the Government, saying: “We cannot advise our local schools it will be safe to reopen yet.”They were joined by a string of other local authorities in the North, including Bury, Hartlepool and Blackburn and Darwen.However Tory MPs in Bury laid into the Labour-run council over the revolt. James Daly and Christian Wakeford urged headteachers to ignore the “political grandstanding” and make their own call.Meanwhile, NEU boss Kevin Courtney has promised to target heads who reopen without sticking to his enormous -page health and safety checklist.It includes a whopping  questions and calls for extra cleaners to wash paint brushes.He told activists in a video call: “We will be talking with our regional secretaries about putting things on social media, saying this school is putting lives at risk.“And we will be threatening heads with thatthey are behaving in those bad ways.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson met union bosses yesterday in a bid to talk them round.The Government has set out five strict tests — including getting death and infection rates down — before schools can reopen for kids in reception, year one and six.The PM’s spokesman stressed it was only “possible” pupils will go back on June , adding: “That will only happenit’s safe to do so.”Labour’s Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham backed the growing council revolt.He said: “There needs to be a little flexibility offered to councils like Bury to put in place the local arrangements to reassure parents, teachers and the wider community.”He added: “If that means a week or a couple of weeks beyond June , I say so be it.”The Government’s senior scientist Angela McLean said the Sage group will assess tomorrowkids can head back on June .Environment Secretary George Eustice said schools must reopen as we start to “live alongside this virus for some time to come”.An NEU spokesman said  school staff in Britain have died from the virus, adding: “It is our duty to protect our members and keep them safe at work during this awful pandemic.”By Kate DochertyKIDS are sending a big “thank you” to their heroic teachers.Pupils posted videos and snaps on social media to mark Thank a Teacher Day today.Grace, , from St Albans, Herts, penned a poem. title: coronavirus epicentre latin america latest
story: The region is now the new epicentre of the coronavirus pandemic with authorities finding bodies in the streets as they struggle to enforce lockdown restrictions.Brazil remains the worst-hit country in Latin America and has the third largest number of infections in the world at more than ,.More than  percent of intensive care beds are full in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo.There are now fears that Latin Americas street markets may have helped spread the killer bug.In Lima, four out of five merchants in the citys major fruit market have tested positive for Covid- while spot tests at five other markets show at least half the workers had the disease.Cops and the military are now carrying out testing at markets after Peru’s president Martín Vizcarra refused to shut down the wholesalers.In the capital, patients took up  per cent of ICU beds as of Friday. The country has the worlds th-highest number of confirmed cases, with more than ,.Infections are also increasing in poor areas of Buenos Aires, the capital of Argentina, where authorities relaxed strict lockdown measures last week, allowing some businesses to open and children to walk outside on weekends.Slums in the city account for  per cent of Covid- cases while the country as a whole has over , infected and a death toll of , official figures show.In Chiles capital Santiago, more than  per cent of intensive care beds were full last week.The citys main cemetery dug , emergency graves to prepare for a wave of deaths.In Colombias Amazon region, cases have shot up in recent weeks, from  at the start of the month to , on Monday.The infections are concentrated in Leticia, a city on the Amazon river that borders both Brazil and Peru.Locals believe its related to the increase in cases in Brazils Amazon.Pictures have emerged of indigenous tribes in the Brazilian state of Amazonas collecting medicinal plants to treat the symptoms of the coronavirus.The indigenous tribes in the region have refused medical help from authorities and prefer to rely on their own ancestral remedies.In Mexico, intensive care occupancy is below  percent in most cities, although deaths have begun to overwhelm funeral homes and crematoriums in the Mexico City borough of Iztapalapa.More than , people have died in the country while over , have tested positive.Covid- is sickening thousands in the Ecuadorian capital of Quito, where  per cent of intensive care beds were occupied as of Friday.“In terms of intensive care, were stripped bare, the citys health secretary Len Mantilla said.But why are cities in the region struggling to cope with the pandemic Some doctors say patients are dying because of a lack of ventilators or because they couldnt get to a hospital fast enough.With intensive care units swamped, officials plan to move patients from capitals like Lima and Santiago to hospitals in smaller cities that arent as busy – a move which risks spreading the disease further.Latin American countries halted international flights and rolled out social distancing guidelines around the same time as the US and Europe, delaying the arrival of large-scale infection, said Dr. Marcos Espinal, of the Pan American Health Organisation.“Latin America was the last wave”, said Dr Espinal, who previously worked at the World Health Organisation.He warned that authorities need to maintain anti-virus restrictions even as the US and Europe reopen.Some of the hardest-hit cities, like Lima and Santiago, imposed strict, early lockdowns - but officials have struggled to enforce them as the poor need to work to feed their families while the wealthy are used to flouting regulations.Latin America is the worlds most unequal region, a reality that Dr Espinal said made it dficult to balance health and economic growth, with millions facing increased poverty during title: organ donation how to opt out uk
story: But what does the scheme entail and how can you opt out The new organ donor opt-out system is a scheme that will regsiter all adults as organ donors when they die.This new law will be put in place from May , .It means youll have to specically sayyou dont want your organs donated - you can do this by ringing    or by filling out an NHS Organ Donor Register withdrawal form.This is commonly referred to as an opt out system.You may also hear the opt-out scheme referred to as, Max and Keiras Law.You still have a choice in whether you want to be an organ donor or not when you die, only now you need to opt out rather than sign up.This can be done by ringing    or by filling out an NHS Organ Donor Register withdrawal form.And some groups of people will be automatically excluded from the new scheme. These groups will include people under , people who have lived in England for less than  months or who are not living here voluntarily, and people who lack the capacity to understand the change.Someone who has currently, or previously had cancer cannot donate organs.There are very few conditions where organ donation is ruled out completely.Other conditions that will rule someone out from organ donation includes those who have HIV or the Ebola virus.In rare cases, the organs of donors with HIV have been used to help others with the same conditions.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sitting 6ft apart may be too closes
story: SITTING ft apart in the park could still spread coronavirus, a new study has found. According to researchers at the University of Nicosia in Cyprus, light winds can blow Covid- droplets as far as ft in five seconds - raising questions around the Governments m rule.Boris Johnson announced last week that Brits can meet up with one other person from another household outdoors - as long as they keep m apart.However researchers at the University of Nicosia in Cyprus, say their findings suggest safety distance guidelines may not be doing enough to prevent the spread of Covid-.For the study, published in the journal Physics of Fluid, the team looked at how saliva travels through the air.They created a computer simulation that looks at how every saliva droplet, large and small, moves through the air after a person coughs.Just one single cough lets out around , droplets, with many of them dispersing in dferent directions.From a sneeze, as many as , droplets might be let out.Dr Talib Dbouk, a senior researcher at the Defense and Security Research Institute at the University of Nicosia said: Each cell holds information about iables like pressure, fluid velocity, temperature, droplet mass, droplet position, etc.The purpose of the mathematical modelling and simulation is to take into account all the real coupling or interaction mechanisms that may take place between the main bulk fluid flow and the saliva droplets, and between the saliva droplets themselves.Results showed that even in the slightest breeze of mph , saliva can travel ft in five seconds.Dr Dimitris Draikakis, a professor in the Medical School and the School of Sciences and Engineering at the University of Nicosia, said: The droplet cloud will affect both adults and children of dferent heights.Shorter adults and children could be at higher riskthey are located within the trajectory of the travelling saliva droplets.This work is vital, because it concerns health and safety distance guidelines, advances the understanding of spreading and transmission of airborne diseases, and helps form precautionary measures based on scientic results.The findings come after the UKs former Conservative Party leader Iain Duncan Smith called for the Prime Minister to consider lowering the two-meter rule to get the economy moving today.But the Government has consistently stuck to its advice, despite previous findings. Back in April, Chinese scientists discovered people with coronavirus could spread the bug to others from ft away.They found virus-laden aerosols were mainly concentrated near and downstream from patients at up to  feet, though smaller quantities were found upstream at up to eight feet.Today, the Government announced the number of coronavirus cases in the UK is nearing ,, after , more infections were confirmed today.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.

title: revellers dance play football coronavirus lockdown
story: DOZENS of young revellers broke the coronavirus lockdown as they gathered to dance, drink and play football on a basketball court.The crowd were seen flouting social distancing rules as they partied outside in Tower Hamlets, East London, on Monday night.Some of the partygoers were seen with balloons at the gathering, as others enjoyed a barbecue.One young child danced next to a group of young women as men kicked a football.Other youths at the shindig rode bikes or scooters around the basketball court, ignoring rules to stay at least two metres apart from other people during the Covid- pandemic.An ice box with drinks stood nearby as the pals mingled.It comes despite strict government guidelines for Brits to maintain social distancing to curb the spread of the virus.Today saw the UKs death toll top ,, after  more people died in the past  hours, including a seven-year-old child.But cooped-up Brits struggling with lockdown have defied government restrictions on social gatherings and travel, sparking fears the lockdown is fraying.Earlier this week, a mum who drove an hour and a half to the seaside left BBC viewers baffled after complaining about others doing the same.Jane Peacock said her day out at Lulworth Cove in Dorset was so busy it was like being in Tesco, adding that many were not social distancing.She told BBC News: Its lovely to get out but Im quite shocked at how many people are here.Theyre not paying attention to social distancing. I find that quite annoying to be honest – its like being in Tesco.And shocking footage emerged of a huge crowd breaking lockdown rules to watch a fight outside a pub streamed on Facebook Live.The brutal brawl was watched by dozens of fans shouting and cheering as the two fighters wearing boxing gloves traded blows in the street.Cops were called to break up the fight outside the Crockets Hotel in Walker, Newcastle on May .In the clip, streamed by , people on Facebook Live, the huge crowd can be seen applauding and screaming as the two fighters batter each other.Meanwhile, a video showed a group of  pals pretending to exercise after they were caught breaking lockdown rules by cops.Footage shows the cop crack a smile as the crowd break into star jumps and jumping jacks as he approaches.One of the group gathered outside a shop, believed to be in Birmingham, shouts high knees and lunges like a fitness instructor.He tells the cop were exercising, sir in the viral video posted on Twitter with the caption: getting the  minutes of exercise with the community.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: doctors union drops opposition schools opening
story: Justice Secretary Robert Buckland today revealed he was not expecting everyone to be back by then, with at least  councils vowing to rebel against the Government plans.Officials have instructed schools to get ready for reception, year one and six to  from the start of June,its safe to still do so.They have issued advice on how to make sure classrooms and playgrounds are as secure as possible - including maximum class sizes of  and keeping desks further apart.However, the plans have sparked a fierce backlash with unions warning teachers not to go, and now councils all over Britain saying they wont force schools to reopen.Among those against the plans are Birmingham, Calderdale council in Yorkshire, and Conservative-controlled Solihull.More councils are expected to join in rejecting the plans today.This morning Mr Buckland insisted the government is still working towards a June  date, but admitted it was not looking good.He said: Im not going to sit here and pretend that suddenly on June  everything will be unorm.We always said the st of June was conditional, not just on the R-rate but the need to make places of work safe.I am hearing what’s being said by our union representatives and brilliant teachers.We have to accept the fact that councils are employers and decisions have to be made collectively.It comes as a doctors union said it no longer opposes the reopening of schools on June .The British Medical Association said evidence shows the risk to kids is extremely small, but schools should only reopenit is “safe to do so.Last week, doctors said it was too risky for kids toto schools, despite the countrys biggest primary school chains backing the Governments plans.In an apparent softening of its stance, the British Medical Associationhas admitted there was “growing evidence that the risk to inidual children from Covid- is extremely small.However, it warned there was still no consensus around how easily kids could spread the disease to vulnerable adults.Writing for The , Dr Peter English, the chairman of the BMA’s Public Health Medicine Committee, said: “The BMA wants schools to reopen as soon as it is safe to do so and the evidence allows – this could be before June  or after.A zero-risk approach is not possible. This is about ‘safe’ being an acceptable level of risk.”Dame Angela McLean, the deputy chief scientic adviser, said an effective track and trace system was needed to isolate those infected by the coronavirus before changes were made to lockdown rules.She told The Times that this should be based on observed levels of infection . . . and not on a fixed date.And scientist John Edmunds, another member of SAGE, told Sky News that a track and trace system must be embedded and working well before schools re-opened.Teaching unions are opposed to the Governments plan to re-open schools on June , claiming teachers, pupils and their families will be at risk of catching the deadly virus.They were backed last week by the British Medical Association, who said unions were absolutely right to urge caution and prioritise testing before reopening schools on June .BMA councils chair, Chaand Nagpaul, the BMA councils chair, said at the time: We cannot risk a second spike or take actions which would increase the spread of this virus, particularly as we see sustained rates of infection across the UK.Kevin Courtney, the joint general secretary of the National Education Union , refused to back down on Tuesday, saying: “Our current assessment is that schools aren’t safe to open, as our five tests have not been met.Butour five tests are met, then on a national level, it would be permissible to go ahead with reopening schools.”According to the Daily Mail, its leaders were caught making a series of slurs in a Zoom meeting last night.The video footage exposed the joint general secretary Mary Bousted accusing children of being mucky by spreading germs and wiping their snot on peoples clothes.The hard-line leaders also discussed how to threaten headteachers should they try to get their staff back to work.The NEU’s five tests include lowering the number of virus cases, plans for social distancing, more testing, strategies for entire schools and protection for the vulnerable.The reopening of primary schools could be delayed beyond June  as local authorities yesterday advised their schools to stay closed, including the first Tory-run council.The Government made clear today that every school’s circumstances were dferent and thata head teacher felt unable to open next month, they should “discuss options” with their local authority or trust. It comes as France makes a mockery of British demands, with teachers ing to French schools wearing masks and taking simple extra precautions.They are among  European to countries which have re-opened classrooms - and evidence suggests that doing so has not been harmful to kids or teachers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
