title: kfc customer horrified after finding feathers poking out
story: The shocked customer slammed the fast food chain as she shared pictures of the fried chicken online, saying she “won’t ever eat KFC again”.The Blackpool woman ordered a KFC from their Cornelian Way branch using Uber Eats, and was left horried after she spotted three feathers poking out from one of the hot wings.The appalled customer posted pictures of food on a community food page yesterday, and said her young son thought the feathers looked like small legs.The woman, who did not want to be named, said: “I have received an apology, refund and also been told that in no circumstances should I have been sent that food.“KFC should not [be] giving this to a customer, surely it’s not good food hygiene to leave feathers attachedthat’s what they are.”The woman later got half her money back from Uber Eats – an £. refund.She told LancashireLive: “I won’t ever eat KFC again.“Because I ordered from Uber Eats I only got a partial refund just for the meal even though the lot was wasted.“When I went to KFC the manager just came over to my car in the car park and he couldn’t give me a refund as I had ordered from Uber.”A KFC spokesman said the feathers were harmless, but said the incident doesnt meet the Colonels usual high standards.He said: Not ideal. Feathers can happen when dealing with fresh chicken - they’re harmless, but it goes without saying they shouldn’t be there.It doesn’t meet the Colonel’s usual high standards, and it’s certainly not the reunion we want people to have with their favourite fried chicken after some time apart! We’re sorry we missed them, so we’d like to invite the customer to get in touch with us and we will make things right.”It comes after a diner in Scotland found a feather in his KFC burger last month.The customer had picked up four mini fillet burgers and two drinks at the firm’s branch in Kilmarnock, Ayrshire and said the experience “put him off KFC for le.”“I took the burger straight back when I saw this.”The woman ordered her meal through Uber Eats from the Cornelian Way branchOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: newly discovered footage tasmanian tiger
story: Shot in , the amazing clip emerged after it was digitally restored by experts from the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.The -second segment comes from a travelogue called Tasmania the Wonderland believed to have been shot by filmmaker and exhibitor Sidney Cook.It captures Benjamin - the last-known surviving thylacine  - at Beaumaris Zoo in Hobart, Tasmania.The fact the video was shot in  makes it the most recent moving images of the now extinct animal.Benjamin died just  months after this startling footage was captured.His death marked the extinction of the species after another specimen died at London Zoo in .Thylacines were large carnivorous marsupials which looked like a cross between a wolf and a big cat.The slow-moving predators hunted kangaroos as well as other marsupials, rodents and small birds.They once lived throughout Australia but became extinct on the mainland around , years ago.It was then confined to the island of Tasmania until they were eventually killed off by dogs and hunters.On the clip Benjamin can be seen pacing around while two men rattle his cage.The narrator says the beast is now very rare, being forced out of its natural habitat by the march of civilization.The scarcity of thylacine footage makes every second of moving image really precious, said NFSA Curator Simon Smith.Were very excited to make this newly-digitised footage available to everyone online.Despite its extinction, Tasmanias Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water and Environment released a document in October detailing eight reported sightings in recent years.However, there has been no hard evidence to support the claims .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teachers schools ready work children back
story: WE cannot wait to see the children back in our schools — teaching them is what we do.While you may hear that teachers’ representatives are not keen for theto the classroom, the reality is completely dferent on the ground.Teachers, generally, really want to help get schools going again.We have just heard from  across our Trust’s schools and over  per cent of them have said they are ready to get back to work.This idea that they are standing in the way of a national effort couldn’t be further from the truth.Our teachers have gone above and beyond the call of duty during this crisis.We have kept the schools open, bank holidays and weekends, for those vulnerable children and those children of key workers.No teacher has ever complained, they have all served their time on a rota.They have been doing amazing work online, marking and preparing for that work, giving feedback.There are bound to be factions and nervousness within the profession, because the health of pupils and staff is a high stakes issue.I am the immediate past president of the Association of School and College Leaders.Our union thinks the right thing to do is to plan, in a considered way, for afrom June .Dferent trade unions have dferent tactics and are using dferent language.We have had hard questions to ask, in regard to safety and how to make it effective.I am not a medic or scientist, so I cannot judge whether we need personal protective equipment.But I can understand the rationale of the Government’s chief medical officer Chris Whitty, when he warns that children fiddling with masks, taking them off and on, is likely to be a greater risk than not having them.Plus, it distracts from the most important measures — which are regular hand washing, good nasal hygiene and making sure we keep things clean in school.The scientic advice is that transmission of Covid- within the school environment is very, very low because of the way in which the virus works in younger people.Based on what we have heard so far from Chris Whitty and the guidance we have seen we think it is safe to put government plans into action.We think we can put the measures in place to reassure parents and staff that it’s the right thing to do.Head teachers are planning for that in detail right now, which is very complex.For example, we have been told we need lidded bins, so everyone is rushing out to buy them.We need to make sure the signage is right, the air conditioning is working, the school is clean.Then you have to deal with the logistics of a maximum of  pupils per class, with a two-metre distance between each pupil.We are working out how many pupils are going to come back, how many staff are available and how much building space have I got There are very good reasons for all these endeavours.It is important for a child’s social and emotional well-being to be able to meet friends at school.We know that children’s access to learning at home will be very iable, because of dferent home broadband speeds and availability of computers.Not everyone has parents who are able to teach them at home.The learning they are missing will be hard to catch up and we don’t want the “coronials”, as they are being referred to, to miss out.They have endured this crisis and now need to be pushed forward to fill the gap in their learning.In our Trust one school in Leeds has  per cent of its pupils on free school meals, while in another the percentage is four or five per cent.We know that those children who don’t have access to great home learning are at a disadvantage.All children need our care and attention, but we worry most about the children whose homes are not a happy or safe place to be.Our message to the Government and everyone  is to work together on the best way to get back into the classroom.We need to work constructively, to chart a way through what is a very complex problem.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on title: aunt woman chopped in half forest of dean
story: Phoenix Netts, , is thought to have been living at a womens refuge in Birmingham when she was killed.Her body was later dumped in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire. Police fear she had been sawn in half and burned.Her devastated aunt, Ana-Liliana Netts, , opened up about the horror of hearing about her nieces tragic death.She told the Mail Online: Im shocked that she has died in such a horric way.I hadnt seen her since she was little, but she was a lovely, sweet-natured girl. Her father used to tell me proudly how clever she was.She used to live in Croydon, she was from a very nice family. They must be heartbroken.I always remember her as a nice little girl. Im so sorry she died like this.Phoenixs family issued an emotional statement in response to her tragic death on May .It read: “As a family we are devastated with what has happened to Phoenix.“We have family and good friends supporting us and our thanks go out to all of them.“We would also like to thank all the police officers involved in the investigation for their hard work and sensitivity.Meanwhile friends of Miss Netts have paid tribute, with one saying: I can’t believe it is her. She was a lovely girl. I thought she had got away from all this.Neighbour Wahidur Rahman, , said: Phoenix was a really nice young girl. She was lovely.I thought something might have happened to her because I hadn’t seen her in a while.It comes after two people appeared in court on Tuesday charged over Phoenixs killing.Gareeca Conita Gordon, , who also lived at the seven-bed refuge in Birmingham, has been charged with murder after the grim discovery was made last week.Married dad-of-two Mahesh Sorathiya, , from Wolverhampton, was charged with assisting an offender after the body parts were discovered.A provisional trial date was set for November  this year.Neighbours reported Phoenix lived at the same womens refuge in Birmingham as Gordon.It is understood the woman was last seen in April with her phone disconnected on Tuesday.Forensic officers were seen at the council-licensed refuge at the weekend combing for clues.Neighbour Wahidur Rahman, , said: Phoenix was a really nice young girl. She was lovely.We didnt know her well - all the women in the refuge kept themselves to themselves. They were all vulnerable in a way.Its so shocking that shes been killed and then cut up.I thought something might have happened to her because I hadnt seen her in a while.The forensics have been in her bedroom for a few days now and today they blacked out the windows.Theyve been taking away bags of belongings.Im just in shock, really. She was a pretty young girl.Tradesman Sorathiya moved to Wolverhampton three years ago from Slough, Berkshire, with his we. The Indian couple are said to have two teenage children.Cops swooped on a man and woman who were said to be driving suspiciously near Coleford, Gloucestershire.They discovered the body parts stuffed in two suitcases. It is understood there had been attempts to burn the remains.Officers later raided a property in Birmingham and discovered the grisly murder scene which is said to have resembled an abattoir, The Sun understands.The judge granted conditional bail to Sorathiya, but no application for bail was made on behalf of Gordon today.Gordon is accused of murder between April  and May , while Sorathiya is accused of assisting her between April  and May .Detective Chief Inspector Scott Grfiths from our homicide team said: “Firstly, I’d like to offer my sincere condolences to Phoenix’s family.“We’ve worked closely with colleagues at Gloucestershire over the past week and our investigation continues at pace.“We’d urge anyone with any information about the tragic loss of Phoenix’s le to get in touch with us.

title: michael gove brussels brexit ideological world economy coronavirus
story: No  has challenged Brussels to ditch its ideological Brexit stance for the good of the coronavirus battered world economy.Michael Gove said there was a powerful incentive for the bloc to compromise and get a deal - warning failure to do so will hit its global reputation.In a move that will heap further pressure on embattled Michel Barnier he even accused eurocrats of putting bureaucracy before people.He said: There is a very powerful incentive for the EU to put the interests of its members and its citizens ahead of ideology.The Cabinet Office minister said the success of the negotiations depends on the EU recognising the UK is a sovereign equal.He told MPs: The EU essentially wants us to obey the rules of their club even though were no longer members.And they want the same access to our fishing grounds as they currently enjoy while restricting our access to their markets.It remains dficult to reach a mutually beneficial agreement while the EU maintains such an ideological approach.But we believe agreement is possibleflexibility is shown.Downing St has published a complete set of legal texts outlining the deal it wants - meaning they can be examined by Member States for the first time.The move comes after UK officials expressed concerns Mr Barnier is struggling to get the attention of EU capitals busy fighting coronavirus.British negotiators hope it will persuade European leaders to get more involved and move on from the blocs hardline stance.They say talks with the Frenchman have hit an impasse as his hands are tied by an un-negotiable mandate.The texts call for a simple Canada-style free trade agreement under which the UK would break free from Brussels red tape.They also outline a separate Norway-style fishing pact, with annual negotiations over access for EU vessels to British waters.Mr Barnier had a dig at how long the UK had kept the texts secret - pointing out Brussels published its plan for a deal two months ago.The PMs chief negotiator David Frost last night accused Mr Barnier of singling out the UK for unfair treatment.In a fiery letter he demanded to know why the bloc wont offer Britain the same access for goods and services it gives many other countries.And he slammed the EU chiefs argument the UK must pay a higher price for a trade deal because of how close it is as hard to justy.He wrote: We find it hard to see what makes the UK, uniquely among your trading partners, so unworthy of being offered the kind of well-precedented arrangements commonplace in modern FTAs.What is on offer is not a fair free trade relationship between close economic partners, but a relatively low-quality trade agreement coming with unprecedented EU oversight of our laws and institutions.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: bbc slash funding cash boost youth network
story: Bosses are considering reviving BBC Three as a broadcast channel - four years after it went online-only - increasing fears that BBC Four could be closed to make room in the schedules.Executives believe that increasing investment in BBC Three will bring in more younger viewers from streaming services such as Netflix.BBC Three — which has developed successful shows such as Normal People and Killing Eve — would see its annual budget increased to between £million and £million, The Times reported last night.The BBC claims in its annual plan, published today, to have “recaptured young people in a dramatic fashion” by making shows available for a year on iPlayer and launching the podcast driven app Sounds but it added that efforts to reach people aged  to  must be intensied.Diverting cash to the youth station at the expense of other television services risks alienating older generations who remain the broadcaster’s most devoted audiences.Insiders have said BBC Four could be downgraded to a repeats station or shut - although the BBC says there are no plans to close it. The governmentaposs roadmap to ease lockdown - which applies to England - says hospitality venues could start to reopen from July  at the earliest. But government sources have repeatedly stressed this might mean cafes or restaurants with outdoor seating areas at first - not pubs. Sources had indicated pubs would not be in the first wave and would only come in later phases, after July - with not even beer gardens allowed to reopen. Meanwhile, scientists have warned some social distancing rules may have to remain until thereaposs a vaccine, making much of pub le impossible. Despite this, Mr Eustice emphasised pubs when he spoke to MPs today in the Commons.  Asked about pubs, he said: As the Prime Minister has outlined, we intend that the hospitality sector - including pubs - would be able to tentatively start gradually opening hopefully during the month of July - subject to the epidemiology supporting such a move. And of course we are already working with the hospitality and pub sector to identy what social distancing measures they might be able to put in place to make that work properly. Mr Eustice said pubs are at the heart of our community and many are facing dficulty - despite being able to operate as take-aways. He told MPs: We recognise that until thingsto something closer to normal and they can reopen normally, hopefully later this summer, then it will not give them all of the trade they previously had.  Downing Street did not confirm or deny that pubs could start reopening as early as July. Asked about Mr Eusticeaposs comments, Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman said: I think that’s a reflection of the detail in the roadmap. That obviously is with the signicant caveat that it has to be safe to do so. Askedplaces reopening would be not just cafes, but pubs as well, he said: The roadmap just talks about hospitality and that would cover pubs.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThese “sickening” images show a terried fox being chased by hounds. The animal was pursued across a field by a pack of dogs as mounted riders were nearby. Campaigners released the video, which was filmed in November, after police and prosecutors decided against taking action against the hunt involved. The shocking film, which lasts one minute,  seconds, shows two riders and about a dozen dogs near a hedge on the edge of a field.  After about a minute, the hounds break off and begin barking as they run down the field. Eventually a fox can be seen running away towards a tree, while a horn can be heard in the background. Sheep in a neighbouring field can be seen running away, and the dogs skirt the edge of the first field along the hedgerow before the footage breaks off. The incident, which unfolded near Okeford Fitzpaine, Dorset and appeared to involve the Portman Hunt, was filmed by Wildle Witness and reported to police. A Wildle Witness spokesman said: “It is sickening to watch this happening  years after hunting was banned. “The legislation needs tightening to prevent foxes being subjected to such terror.  “We will continue to monitor the activities of hunts and bring in to the public domain the reality of what is happening in our countryside.” Hunting with hounds was banned on February ,  following the  Hunting Act’s approval by Parliament. But trail hunting, where where riders accompanied by hounds follow a scent along a pre-determined route, is allowed. It is meant to replicate a traditional hunt but without a fox being chased, maimed or killed. Dorset Police confirmed it received a report “in relation to an alleged illegal fox hunt that had been witnessed in the area of Okeford Fitzpaine near Blandford”.  A force spokesman said a “local officer carried out an investigation into the incident and two men attended for voluntary interviews with officers”. The spokesman added: “Evidence was compiled and following consultation with the Crown Prosecution Service, a decision was made not to bring any charges in relation to the case. “Dorset Police will investigate any alleged breached of the Hunting Act  and other legislation and will work closely with the Crown Prosecution Service to determinea case could be taken to court. “Hunting mammals with dogs has been illegal since .  “A few, very specic, exemptions apply. “We would urge anyone with clear evidence of such offending to please report it to us.” A spokesman for the Portman Hunt said: “The Portman Hunt operates within the law by carrying out lawful trail hunting activities. “As has been proven on numerous occasions in court, the evidence provided by anti-hunting activists almost always fails to support their claims of illegal hunting activity. “This has been proven yet again by the authorities investigating this case who have said there will be no further action. “Anti-hunting activists are aware that the circulation of their edited footage online using social media s can amply their highly emotive messages, regardless of the facts, but this often results in hundreds of hours of wasted police time, which is totally unacceptable.” League Against Cruel Sports campaigns director Chris Luffingham said: “If ‘trail’ hunting is real then in no circumstances should animals be chased by hounds, it simply wouldn’t happen.

title: hope brits holiday parks prepare
story: NewsHope for Brits as holiday parks prepare to reopen this summer for staycationsSome of the UKs leading holiday parks are putting plans in place to reopen this summer with new rules that will allow families to maintain social distancingShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsBrits may get summer holidays after all " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK’s top holiday parks and resorts are preparing for a summer boom as tourism bosses urge lockdown-weary Brits to enjoy a staycation and help boost the ailing sector. Haven, Center Parcs and Butlin’s are drawing up plans to adapt their sites to cater for families’ “pent-up demand to get away” while sticking to vital social distancing rules.They are hoping the Government clears holiday parks and resorts to reopen in July – under what would be Phase Three of Boris Johnson ’s plan to ease us out of lockdown and reboot the hospitality sector.It comes after Visit Britain said the domestic market, worth £billion, has already lost £billion as a result of Covid- measures. The group wants families to make  the “year of domestic tourism”. Acting chief executive Patricia Yates told the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee: “To get British tourism up and running this summer – and the summer is hugely important – you’re going to need that domestic audience.” She added there was “a real job to be done” to convince people it is acceptable to “enjoy a holiday and that it’s safe to do so”. But figures from coolcamping. com, covering  locations, show summer bookings for campsites have soared % in the past week. The website said: “There’s clearly a pent-up demand to get away. The mooted date of July  is ideal timing for summer and could save many businesses who have had no income.” Rethinks on how resorts and parks operate will help reassure people mulling a staycation. Haven says planned measures range from Perspex screens at reception and info desks to check-ins from home. On-site grocery stores will have the same social distancing rules as supermarkets, while restaurants will just do takeaways and deliveries. Hand- washing stations will be dotted around all  parks and there will be reduced numbers on sites – with communal areas like swimming pools will staying closed.Haven said: “Our prices have been adjusted to recognise the revised experience. We’ve made signicant changes, which we anticipate will allow us to open as soon as Government deems it safe. We’ll comply with coronavirus restrictions.”Center Parcs, which has six UK sites, is also hoping to reopen in July and said holidaymakers could expect to see “some changes”. A spokesman said: “We are reviewing the whole experience to ensure we can open with appropriate social distancing as well as any other measures required to keep our staff and guests safe. “We know we can adapt and provide reassurance to guests and staff, and will only reopen when the time is right. When we do, we are confident we will provide a great guest experience for families.” Butlin’s said fewer people would be allowed in entertainment venues and it would increase the number of shows. There will be more sittings for meals as well as extra events so that kids do not miss out on activities. The firm said: “We are awaiting guidance as to when we can reopen. “In the meantime, we’re using all of the skills and creativity of our team to plan a break that keeps everyone safe.” The Camping and Caravanning Club, which represents , sites, said caravanners will park six metres apart and tents will also be pitched with large gaps between them. Its plans include asking campers and caravan owners to bring their own portable loos so toilets can stay closed. Bosses offered to do a trial reopening after losing £million of bookings due to Covid-. Camping and Caravanning Club director general Sabina Voysey said: “We’re well-placed to offer socially-distanced holidays and eager to work on trial schemes for how campsites may reopen with all necessary measures. “We urge the Government to provide greater clarity on how the sector can safely open and operate.” The plans to get staycations firmly on the radar emerged as airlines slammed a bid by Transport Secretary Grant Shapps to boost uptake of foreign holidays as unworkable. Mr Shapps raised hopes of travel to top hotspots by striking up no-quarantine deals, or “air bridges”, with countries where infection rates are low. Britain’s biggest tour operator, Tui, said it hopes to kick-start the season from June . The firm got a boost after Portugal and Greece revealed they were willing to relax quarantine restrictions for Britsit was a two-way system. Algarve Tourism Board head Joao Fernandes said: “If British holidaymakers are allowed to fly to countries with low infection rates via ‘air bridges’, without having the need for quarantine, the Algarve will be the place to be.” But airlines said the scheme was at odds with the Government’s two- week quarantine rules for anyone coming into the UK, effective from next month, and a Foreign Office ban on non-essential travel abroad. The PM’s official spokesman said air bridges were “an option under consideration but not agreed policy”.

He still cycles to restaurants and takeaways, picks up the food then rides to the customeraposs house to drop it off. But the reason behind many of his orders is now dramatically dferent, and heaposs no longer just delivering a lazy dinner but providing an essential service to the most vulnerable people in our community. Since lockdown was brought in, the delivery company has started working with convenience shops to take groceries to people who are self-isolating or shielding.  Robin, , has been a driver with the delivery company for four years, but admits he did consider quitting when the lockdown was introduced. He told : There were a couple of days when I felt like I really didnapost want to go out, but then as time passed I realised that I should. I was more concerned at the start, it was just a complete shock. It was a shock for everybody. People are so grateful for us to bringing their stuff to them. Itaposs a great feeling, it feels like youaposre contributing to keeping people safe. People used to order for a treat but now theyaposre ordering because they really need stuff and they donapost want to leave their house.  One moment that sticks in his mind is when a customer left him a thank you note and a chocolate bar to thank him for dropping groceries off to her. The note said: Hereaposs a wee treat to get you through the rest of your sht. Robin, who has been a Deliveroo driver for four years and lives with his girlfriend, who is also a key worker, said: Iaposve never been tipped in chocolate before. It was so nice and I really wasnapost expecting it. Itaposs good knowing youaposre helping people.  Robin does everything he can to protect himself and customers while out delivering, like all his Deliveroo colleagues. He uses hand sanitiser before entering and once heaposs left each restaurant, and does the same as he arrives at the customeraposs house. While there have been a lot more orders, the quieter roads have made the actual delivering part of the job much easier. Robin said: Weaposre not seeing as much of the customers, itaposs down from about  per cent to about  per cent. Weaposre leaving the food on the doorstep. But thereaposs still a little bit of contact from a distance. His fellow driver Alex Smith, , delivers in Horsham alongside his university studies.  He knew he wanted to carry on working as soon as he saw how grateful people were, and heaposs made a mini documentary about his time out delivering. He said: I was determined to carry on. I did it for a little bit, and then I saw how important it was to vulnerable people. Being able to help someone is really nice. There are vulnerable people who canapost get food, and being able to deliver to them is important. People are saying thank you for working, it just made me think that someone has got to do it and I want to be the one to do it.  What I like most is how grateful people are. People are really nice when youaposre dropping off. Like Robin, Alex is making sure heaposs doing everything he can to keep customers safe and following all the procedures, but admits he tries not to think about the personal risk. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMax Johnson has pleaded for more organ donors to help save the lives of tots such as little Ethan Eaves. The -year-old heart swap boy spoke as experts revealed the coronavirus crisis has led to a slump in transplants. It comes as Max and Keira’s Law on opt-out donation is rolled out across England on Wednesday – after a four-year campaign by the Mirror. Max said: “I would say to people today… don’t waste your organs when you die.” Ethan,  months, has been waiting in hospital for a heart since August to replace his enlarged one. The brave -year-old urged more people to consider becoming donors – on the eve of the opt-out rule bearing his name and that of the little girl who saved his le being adopted in England.  As doctors prepare to start ramping them up again, Max pleaded: “If you can save lives when you die, why wouldn’t you ” One of those lives is -month-old Ethan, who has been waiting for a heart since August to replace his enlarged one. The tot is hooked up to an articial heart as mum Roseleila and dad Richard look on helplessly. Max and Keira’s Law, which came after a four-year campaign by the Mirror for an opt-out rule, does not apply to under s and parents still have to give permission for doctors to use their children’s organs. But Roseleila and Richard could face an even longer wait due to the ­coronavirus pandemic.  Some patients have had to be taken off the transplant list because the risk to them of receiving an organ is too high. No one who dies showing Covid- symptoms can donate. Those who are able to be treated, such as kidney patients on dialysis, may be expected to wait longer for operations. But those in dire need of transplants, who would die without an organ, will still have surgery. Max was given his heart by the family of nine-year-old Keira Ball, who died in a car accident near her home at ­Barnstaple, Devon, in . She also saved three others. His parents Paul, , and Emma, , and Keira’s mum Loanna and dad Joe are working hard to raise awareness of the new law – which was inspired by their children. Loanna, , who was seriously injured in the crash that killed her daughter, said: “Max and Keira will be remembered long after we are gone. “This law is so important. They really will go down in history, they will never be forgotten. That means so much.” The couple’s charity, Inspired by Keira, is helping bereaved parents cope with the loss of a child. And they worked tirelessly to help the , currently on the organ donor list. Loanna and Joe also work hard to reassure parents who might consider organ donationthe ­unthinkable were to happen, and they were to lose a child. Paul and Emma, of Winsford, Cheshire, wrote a book called Golden Heart, in which they vividly describe the ordeal of parents whose children are on the transplant list. For Max, it was nine months on a ward at Newcastle’s Freeman Hospital looking out of the window, wonderingand when he might be saved.  Even at , he was thinking of others, admitting he might not make it. But he still believed the new law was right. For five-year-old Frankie Lord, who was in the Freeman at the same time as Max and featured in the Mirror on Tuesday, it was a -month wait for his parents Sophie and Chris as they watched the agony of their little boy clinging to le. Emma said: “What I say to people is how would you feel about organ ­donationyour child needed an organ  “If one of your loved ones needed a transplant, would you accept a donor organ  I think that is the best way of looking at it…you would take one, you should be prepared to give.”  Civil servant Paul added: “Max has never forgotten the children on the ward who did not make it. “He remembered them when we decided to join the Mirror campaign almost exactly three years ago. And he still remembers them now.” Max, who has a -year-old brother, Harry, has formed an unbreakable bond with Loanna and Joe and their ­children Bradley, , Katelyn, , and -year-old Keely – who he calls his “second family”. Both the Johnsons and Balls paid tribute to Mirror readers, who backed our campaign to reform the organ law – which now assumes everyone is a donor unless they opt out.  Experts believe it will give surgeons  more organs to ­transplant ­annually, saving hundreds of lives each year. Thousands signed up to join the organ donor register, and petition Parliament for change. It was backed by footballer Andy Cole – who received a kidney from his nephew Alexander Palmer – surgeon Sir Magdi Yacoub, The British Heart Foundation, Kidney Care UK, the British Medical Association and Kaylee Davidson-Olley, the first successful and longest surviving baby transplant in Europe after receiving her heart at just five months old. NHS Blood and Transplant had a huge rise in the number of donors signing up. Its medical director for organ ­donation, John Forsythe, said: “As the situation with Covid- is ever changing, so is the picture regarding donation and transplantation. “Some units have made the dficult decision to close their transplant programmes for now. This to support the NHS in treating Covid- patients.  “Lesaving transplants are still going ahead as long as clinical staff feel it is safe. Transplant teams will talk to patients and balance their need against the additional challenges of being immunosuppressed at this time and the challenges being faced within the NHS at this moment.” Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “Coronavirus has vividly reminded us that le is a precious gt, one that we must do all we can to treasure and protect. “It’s why the new organ donor opt-out law, which comes into force today, is so important.” How Mirror helped bring in donor law April  Teddy Houlston became Britain’s youngest donor, donating his organs after dying aged just  minutes. It led to more than , people signing the organ donor register.  December  The soft opt-out system comes into force in Wales after a  law change. The Daily Mirror launches its Change the Law for Le campaign calling for legislation change in England too.  July  Labour MP Geoffrey Robinson came up in the Private Members’ Ballot and chose to use it to change the law to presumed consent in England.  September  We revealed that  Brits could have been saved that yearan opt-out system had been in place.  October  Prime Minister Theresa May gave the bill government backing.  February  The bill finally becomes law after passing its final hurdle in the House of Lords. A huge public information campaign begins to let people know thatthey do not opt out, it is assumed that they consent to donate. May  The law comes in to force. Transplants up after Covid- shutdown By Health Editor Martin Bagot Lesaving transplants are being ramped up again as Max and Keira’s Law comes in to force on Wednesday. Most operations had been delayed due to fears vulnerable patients might contract Covid- during surgery. And health minister Lord Bethell has said that while NHS bosses had no choice but to impose the policy many organs had been “wasted” as a result. Care minister Helen Whately told the Commons yesterday “over , people in England are waiting for a transplant”. She said: “During the peak of the pandemic, there were many days that there were no transplants. “As of last week there have been  referrals,  donors and  transplants. “We have a duty now more than ever to push ahead with measures that will reduce human suffering and help people improve their quality of le. “That is exactly what this law does.” The law presumes all adults in England agree to be donors unless they opt out. Anthony Clarkson, of NHS Blood and Transplant, said: “We hope this will prompt all of us to consider whether or not we want to donate our organs.” Fiona Loud, of Kidney Care UK, said it “gives a shining light of hope” to the hundreds needing a kidney transplant. “Capacity and resource must be built back up so that precious organs do not go to waste.”  aposHave that conversation for kids like my Ethanapos By Julie McCaffrey and Grace Macaskill All day and night, Roseleila Eaves has her phone on full charge, the ringtone set to loud and always within easy reach. Becausea call comes to say a donor heart has become available, -month-old son Ethan’s le depends on it. The tot has been in Great Ormond Street Hospital since August last year and is hooked up to an articial heart. All he knows is that the cannulas get in the way of his crawling practice. He is blissfully unaware they are keeping him alive until a tiny heart transplant takes place. His family, who have been warned the coronavirus outbreak means longer waits for transplant ops, are appealing for parents to talk about donation should the worst happen.  Roseleila, , from Luton, says: “I can only imagine how raw and devastating a conversation about organ donation could be when a parent has just lost a child. “But NHS studies have found many parents have said in hindsight they would have agreed. “Many young lives would be savedthose conversations were had now. Talk to each other and talk to your childrenthey’re old enough, so you know their wishes. Today, the day Max and Keira’s Law comes into force, marks  days since Ethan’s been on the urgent transplant list.” Ethan was diagnosed with an enlarged heart in August , seven months after engineer dad Richard, , had a transplant for a dferent heart condition. He was born a healthy lb oz and when sent for a routine heart test because of his family background was given the all clear. But on the couple’s first wedding anniversary on August , Ethan was rushed to hospital after falling ill and an X-ray found his heart was enlarged. In a -hour op, Ethan was wired to a mechanical heart after his own began beating dangerously fast.  “Sadly, it’s not a cure and comes with a risk of blood clots,” says Roseleila. “He desperately needs the transplant. Every night when I leave him in hospital tohome to my husband and two older children, I become emotional and so does Ethan.” Max and Keira’s Law does not apply to under-s and parents still have to give permission for doctors to use their organs. Before the pandemic, children waited an average  days for a transplant – compared with  for adults. More than  kids in the UK need an organ transplant and  of them are waiting for a heart. The size of the heart is important, meaning a donor of a similar size is needed. A young donor is their only hope. But for some, the call never comes. Amelia Brown has been waiting for a new kidney since she was born eight years ago. She has serious renal problems caused by vacterl syndrome. A transplant is her only hope of enjoying simple childhood joys. Mum Gemma, , of Sheffield, says: “Amelia stays positive by saying things like, ‘When I get a new kidney I’ll be able to jump really high’. “She stays cheerful and positive and that helps me and my husband, Jason. The idea of the transplant never happening is unthinkable. “That’s why we urge families to have the conversation about organ donation. People often avoid them because it’s too awful to think about.But for many parents of children on the transplant list, that’s the reality.Follow Ethan’s journey on Instagram at @ethaneaves_ Campaigneraposs perfect birthday gt By Warren Manger Max and Keira’s law is the birthday present Christine Cox has dreamed of for  years. Christine,  today, began campaigning to change the law after her brother Peter died of a brain tumour in  aged .

The Government#xs plans to start sending children back to school next month have come under attack from teaching unions and some local authorities, with critics arguing it is too soon to lt the lockdown restrictions.Stand Up to Racism co-convenor Weyman Bennett said that BAME communities should not send their children to school until the Government sets out a plan for making sure it is safe. Clare Milward said she found the matted green mass in the bottom of a carton of Apple, Lime and Mint from Crafted Drinks. The company have said the packaging must have become damaging after leaving the factory. Clare, who is married with two sons aged ten and , said: Iaposm not sureit was related, but all week I felt nauseous and had a funny tummy and could not eat anything other than bland foods.We have been staying home and washing our hands regularly because of coronavirus, andit was food poisoning from something  then the whole family would have had it as we have eaten the same things.We, as a family, have decided not to use cartons again, only see-through bottles. Recalling when she found the lump, she said: I poured it out and saw a green fleck in it. I thought maybe I had not done the washing up thoroughly and it was a bit of parsley in the glass. But I had a sip and thought, aposthis isnapost rightapos. Clare, from Lancing, West Sussex, thought it could be a piece of mint. She says that when she cut the carton open she was horried to find a lump of green mould. The company said the packaging must have become damaged because it carries out stringent checks on products before they go on sale.  Clare said: It was not open or anything, I think air must have got in somehow. I could still see some mould on the inside of the carton and around the plastic where the drink is poured from, so I think it was sitting at the top. I was pretty disgusted by the amount of mould, it was well in date - the carton said it was best before November this year.For that amount of mould to build up, how long has it been festering for  Clare emailed the company, hoping for a robust reaction.  But she was disappointed by Crafted Drinksapos response. She said: I always think you should give the company a chance to reply, so messaged them privately, but they just said sorry and gave me a £ voucher. I said I would like them to respond in a robust way but they did not respond. I have got the mould but they donapost want to test it or anything. A Crafted Drinks spokesman said: We take the quality of our products extremely seriously and follow the highest standards throughout the production process.  Detailed checks are made on all batches and products are held until final quality control checks have been undertaken before they are released for sale. In addition, samples from each batch are retained so that we can review them and carry out further testsever required. This is exactly what we did on this occasion. Due to this, we are completely confident in the quality of the product that left the premises. Therefore, we can only assume that some sort of damage occurred to the packaging within the supply chain, which unfortunately, while very rare, can happen to any perishable item such as food.

title: radioactive compass saved brit tank
story: NewsHeroic story of how a radioactive compass saved Brit tank crew from Nazi captureA glow-in-the-dark compass that helped the WWII tank crew on their epic -day trek to the River Somme to evade capture will go on display in a museum in DorsetShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA radioactive compass helped a Second World War tank crew escape from Nazis after losing their battalion during a battle. Marked with radium paint to glow in the dark, it helped them evade capture in an -day trek that ended with one of them being rescued wearing just his underpants and beret after crossing the River Somme. Brigadier Peter Vaux, Major Stewart Fernie and Lance Corporal Robert Burroughs had found themselves isolated and surrounded during the Battle of Arras in May . But they bravely dodged German patrols, hid in farms and woodland in northern France and scavenged for food. At one point they were caught by a German officer, who Brig Vaux shot dead at close range. With the aid of the compass, they made it to the River Somme, where they met a Belgian interpreter who gave Brig Vaux some civilian clothes. The men cut a path to the river while taking notes on the whereabouts of the German patrols, but became separated crossing the river at night. On the other side Brig Vaux walked up the river bank clad in just underpants and a beret until, exhausted, he was picked up by French troops, who reunited him with Maj Fernie and the compass.  But L Cpl Burroughs had been swept downstream and drowned. Brig Vaux wrote: “On th June we left France and at am on th June caught our first glimpse of Weymouth Bay. “Never, I think have I ever seen anything so beautul.” He went on to fight in the Western Desert and was promoted to GSO in General Horrocks’ th Corps for the Battle of El Alamein.

story: NewsBrits could enjoy summer camping holidays with sites set to reopen in JulyWork and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey said campsites are eager to reopen this summer as Brits face not being able to travel abroad, with some possibly reopening in JulyShareCommentsByJamie Hawkins:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsCampsites could reopen in July " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCampsites could be allowed to open this summer, a senior government minister has said.The coronavirus pandemic has left it increasingly unlikely Brits will be able to holiday abroad this summer, with countries still imposing strict lockdowns.However, camping holidays could be allowed to go ahead, with some sites possibly opening in July. Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey told Sky: I know there are a lot of campsites that are very keen for people to come.  Some of this is being carefully considered, recognising that we have a reduced outdoor transmission risk, that things like camping may well become suitable. But that is a decision that still needs to be taken for later this year, potentially in July or even later in the year, recognising that we need to do all we can to keep that R rate below one, the number of infections down, and we need to be careful when we take those steps. Caravan sites are also hoping to open to the public this summer. Holiday companies, such as Haven holiday par,k have revealed ways that they would reopen.  Currently all of the chainaposs  parks remain closed until July . However, staff are working towards welcoming guests back when it is safe to do so whilst ensuring they comply with the coronavirus restrictions. If youaposre planning on booking a holiday with Haven when they reopen then you sadly wonapost be able to use the swimming pool, enjoy activities, entertainment or eat in the pubs and restaurants. But you will be able to book a holiday home, order takeaway food and use the open beaches.  Itaposs all part of the aposHaven Hideawayapos which aims at still giving families a much needed break while following social distancing rules. The company says that prices for these holidays have been adjusted to reflect the experience and guests who already have breaks booked during this period will not be affected at this stage. Gerard Tempest, guest and proposition director, said: “We have thousands of guests who have already had breaks cancelled this year due to the coronavirus pandemic.  “We look forward to reopening our parks as soon as government advice allows and as soon it is safe to do so, and are busy making changes to the way we operate our parks to ensure we can comply with the latest requirements. story: NewsTop ways to stay healthyyouve got diabetes during coronavirus pandemicIf you have diabetes type  or prediabetes, regular exercise is crucial to improve your blood sugar controlShareCommentsByClare Fitzsimons:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPeople with diabetes during this time need to take extra care " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDespite the recent relaxing of lockdown rules,​ staying active remains tougher than ever, with gyms and swimming pools still closed. However,you have diabetes type  or prediabetes, regular exercise is crucial to improve your blood sugar control. Getting fit will also reduce your risk of suffering from further complications such as heart disease and stroke. But you don’t have to become a marathon runner overnight – or indeed start any form of extreme workout. Instead, just increasing your activity levels by a moderate amount can make a huge dference. Always consult your doctor before starting any new exercise plan, especiallyyou have diabetes or any other underlying conditions. How does exercise help with diabetes  When you move about more, your muscles work harder, which means they use up more of their favourite fuel – glucose . Because exercising requires your muscles to burn off excess glucose for energy, it lowers your all-important blood sugar levels. Dr Sarah Brewer says: “Exercise is incredibly important for diabetic patients. It lowers blood sugar and stress levels, which make it helpful in both preventing the disease and controlling it.” How much is enough  People with diabetes type  or prediabetes should get the same recommended  minutes of moderate exercise a week as the rest of us – but should take care not to miss more than two days of exercise in a row to maintain a healthy weight and steady blood sugar. In other words, about  minutes of exercise, five days a week. Aerobic activity at moderate intensity basically means exercising at a level that raises your heart rate and gets you a little bit out of breath. This can include outdoor pursuits such as brisk walking, gentle jogging, bike riding, tennis and golf – all of which are now allowed. Break it up To make the -minute weekly target even more achievable, your daily exercise quota can be broken up into -minute chunks throughout the day, so it’s easier to fit in. With a bit of imagination, most days in lockdown are full of opportunities to get your body moving. Pick and mix from the following activities to help make up your  minutes of exercise, five days a week target. Move to the beat Play your favourite music loud and get moving at home. Dancing is one of the best forms of exercise and is great for losing weight, improving posture, boosting mood and beating stress. Just  minutes of jiving can burn nearly  calories. And the more energetic your moves are the better.  A good clean win Spending so much time at home can mean we have to clean the house more than ever, so why not put in a bit of added elbow grease and make it count as exercise  For example, mopping the floor for  minutes burns  calories, while vigorous vacuuming can burn  calories an hour. The bonus is you’ll be left with a gleaming house! Get the garden sorted Gardening is great exercise that you don’t even realise you’re doing on a nice day outside. Researchers at Kansas State University found it could help strengthen your limbs, boost your heart health and encourage flexibility. And just half an hour of proper digging will burn up to  calories! So get weeding, pruning and mow that early summer lawn. You could even boost your diet and save cash by growing your own veg. Spending time in the garden also has the added bonus of boosting your levels of Vitamin D – the immune-boosting nutrient made by sunlight on skin - which can become deficientwe spend long periods indoors. Workout in your home office It’s amazing how many calories you can burn while sat down – just by moving your limbs a bit more. If you’re at a home desk, try marching your feet up and down on the spot for a few minutes – this will work the large muscles in your legs. For easy calf exercises, simply raise your feet up on the toes and lower them. And to tone your tummy, sit up straight and pull your stomach muscles in towards your spine. Keep breathing normally and hold this position for  seconds. Count your steps Hit the well-known , steps a day target for a full week and you will have done roughly the same level of activity as the recommended  weekly minutes of exercise. However, even with the more relaxed lockdown, we’re all typically walking less at the moment. Soyou have a pedometer, a fitness tracker or even an iPhone, which all have built-in activity monitors, carry it at all times to check you’re achieving the target number of steps each day. A few steps short today  Use the extra daylight to head outside for a brisk evening walk. Lt some beans You can exercise without any equipment at all – saving the cost of buying expensive gym kit. For example, why not use a couple of cans of baked beans to strengthen your arms  Simply hold your “weights” down by your sides with your palms facing forwards. Then, without moving the upper part of your arms, slowly bend your arm at the elbow, bringing the cans up to your shoulders. Return to the starting position, keeping each movement slow. Repeat - times per arm.

A lot of people with a foot fetish like the stinky smell, but it’s super hard for me to get my feet to stink. The client was still happy though, even though they smelled like my coconut foot mask!  Sweet, who lives in Portland in Oregon, US, also works in a hospital theatre, but earns a lot more with her foot work - often up to £, a year. “After one month of doing this, I tripled my hospital income as a surgical assistant - which is ,before tax. It’s insane. “Having a foot fetish myself, I started doing it for fun a year ago, just to share pictures of my cute feet. I didn’t think I could make a living from it.” Sweet Arches says she has been fascinated by her own and other peopleaposs feet since childhood.  “I have always had a foot fetish, enjoying pedicures and making sure my feet look good,” she recalled. “Even when I was very young, Iaposd always compliment people on their feet or randomly give foot massages to my friends, whereas most people think feet are weird. According to Chinese media six officials from both cities have been removed from their pots following the new cluster of cases. New measures in the province of Jilin have seen trains and buses have been cut off, schools shut, and thousands being put into strict lockdown. Chinese people in the area have expressed their frustration at the new measures which have quashed hopes that le could soonto normal. “Everyone is jittery,” said Wang Yuemei, a pharmaceutical factory worker in neighboring Tonghua, told  Bloomberg News.“I never ever expected Jilin province to be a hard-hit area when the whole country is getting back to normal now.” Shulan went into lockdown last week quarantined some , people in a failed bid to contain the second outbreak. Fengman District has recorded  cases of local infection in the same period and was put on lockdown on Monday after a -point directive from the local health commission. The travel restrictions include bans on all outbound foot and vehicle traffic, as well as the closure of schools and entertainment venues such as cinemas, gyms and restaurants. Residential districts have been put on closed management, with each household allowed to send one member to shop for essentials once a day. All shops and the majority of supermarkets in the districts also shut on Monday, reports added, while city officials were also gathering testing kits and protective equipment for health workers. Images show shutter doors closed and streets barricaded and nearing empty as the restrictions came into place at the weekend.  Following an order on May , the Jilin Ice Sports Center was converted into a field hospital in  hours and is now ready to accept patients. It was still unclear which category of patients would be sent to the winter sports arena. Last week, footage also showed secondary school pupils being sent home as case numbers grew. Classes had only just resumed on April  after much of China declared victory of the coronavirus outbreak. It comes as the city of Wuhan ordered all  million residents to be tested for coronavirus.  Dubbed the ‘-day battle’, the Chinese city officials launched a campaign on Thursday, May , after the Wuhan Health Commission announced a cluster of six new infections - the first since the city ended its two-month lockdown on Wednesday, April . Authorities have said the ambitious plan may be the only way to identy all asymptomatic carriers in the city, where residents remain wary and concerned about a second wave of infections.

title: seven new coronaviruses found lurking
story: NewsSeven new coronaviruses found lurking in bats in AfricaThe new strains of coronavirus were reportedly found in bats in Gabon, but scientists say it is currently unclear whether they can spread to humans and cause a new pandemicShareCommentsByJamie Hawkins:,  MAY NewsExperts say seven new coronaviruses have been found in Gabon, Africa " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSeven new coronaviruses have been discovered in bats, according to reports. The new strains of the virus were reportedly found in Gabon, Africa, but it is not clear whether they can spread to humans.According to NewScientist, experts from the Franceville International Medical Research Center recently tested more than a thousand bats living in caves across the country and found that  of them had coronavirus.The research found that five of the new seven coronaviruses are linked to previous strains that were linked to humans. These include the human coronavirus E that has been circulating among humans since the s, which usually causes only mild cold symptoms. This has led to the scientists speculating that the new coronaviruses could spread to humans, causing another pandemic, but added further research would need to be done first. Genetic sequencing also showed that seven of these coronaviruses, all of which have been found in bats that eat insects, have been completely unknown so far. Speculation continues as to where this particular coronavirus, which has brought the world to a standstill, originated from. The Covid- genome is thought to have come from bats captured from caves in Yunnan. The caves are , miles away from Wuhan, the Chinese city which is now infamous for having been the epicentre of the global coronavirus pandemic. Scientists say it is highly likely that Covid- first came from bats, but first passed through an intermediary animal before jumping to humans. It is widely believed that the flu-like virus first began infecting humans in late  after being transmitted from an animal at the Huanan seafood market. However, UK government sources said that while the balance of scientic advice is still behind the animal market theory, an accident at a Wuhan laboratory is no longer being discounted. The experiments, which relate to the origin of coronaviruses, are said to have been paid for by a .m grant from the US government. Funded by the US National Institutes of Health, the results of the research were published in November  under the heading: Discovery of a rich gene pool of bat SARS-related coronaviruses provides new insights into the origin of SARS coronavirus. Scientists are uncertain about several aspects of the origin of Covid-, with fresh doubts also arising last week following research by Cao Bin, a doctor at the Wuhan Jinyintan Hospital, which found that  of the first  diagnosed patients had not had any contact with the market. However, responding to the claims, the Chinese Embassy has described speculation around the labaposs activities as hasty and reckless allegations.

title: craig conway film jon daly dundee united scottish cup
story: Craig Conway has revealed he warmed up for Scottish Cup glory with Dundee United by watching “The Commitments” with Jon Daly.Conway’s two goals in the th and th minute, following David Goodwillie’s opener, secured the Cup for United in  and sealed the winger’s place in Tangerines folklore.Around , Terrors fans travelled through to Glasgow for the showpiece occasion, many wracked with nerves.But Conway was totally relaxed before producing his man-of-the-match performance.“The night before the Final I was sharing a room in the team hotel with big Jon Daly,” said the -year-old, currently with Salford City.“We just tried to have a quiet time and then watched the film The Commitments.“I didn’t really have trouble sleeping. To be fair, I am usually like that before a big game.“I had already gone through everything in my mind about what I wanted to do on the pitch and how to prepare.”Conway, who has also played for Cardf City and Blackburn Rovers, added: “There was little in the final itself as we went in at half-time with the scores level.“But I was always sure thatwe kept doing what we had been doing the first goal would come.“Thankfully it did and then I was able to get my two goals as well.“It is something you are always asked: ‘Is it the sort of thing you dream about when you are a kid,’ and genuinely it is.“When you are playing in the park with your mates, you hope that one day you can score in the Scottish Cup Final so to do it was one of the highlights of my career and one of the best feelings you can get.“Once the final whistle goes, it is all a bit of a blur but it was just great to see the sheer delight on everyone’s faces.“It is so hard to put into words exactly how you felt but there was a massive sense of achievement.”After the trophy was handed to United, the celebrations really took off on the way back to Dundee before the players partied the night away alongside ecstatic fans, with Conway heading for his favourite city night spot.“It was just carnage on the bus with all sorts of nonsense back to the club and then it was into the town to celebrate,” said the seven-times-capped ex-Scotland star.“I’d had a lot of nights out in Fatties but everyone was just having a great time and it was the best atmosphere ever there.“Everybody was absolutely buzzing and it was great to be able to celebrate with the fans.“Everyone was together like a big family.“After a couple of hours’ sleep, we then had the parade on the open-top bus.‘To be honest, a lot of us were still drunk! In fact the celebrations continued for most of that week.“We had expected the fans to turn out but we were absolutely stunned by the thousands in the city square and at Tannadice. It is something that will stay with me forever.“The  years have just flown by but there will always be a special bond with the lads.“It was one of the best days of my career and my medal still has pride of place in a room in my house.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

story: The result of Tuesday’s failed SPFL inquiry vote has vindicated Dundee managing director John Nelms, according to a Dark Blues fan chief.Following weeks of back-biting and sniping over the Dens Park supremo’s now infamous voting U-turn at the start of April, two thirds of league clubs voted against an independent inquiry.With nine out of  Championship clubs voting ‘no’, chairman of the Dundee Supporters# Association, Kenny Ross, believes a “clear statement” has been made in relation to Nelms# actions.And Ross also insists the response from Dundee fans at large has been one of acceptance.He told the Tele: “The club seem quite relaxed about what’s been going on the past couple of weeks, not saying anything.“John Nelms doesn’t say much at the best of times but I think that relaxed attitude is echoed by the fans.“With nine out of  Championship clubs voting no, there is also a clear statement there and I think it vindicates John Nelms.“Personally, I would have liked an inquiry because there are questions that need answered but it was pretty overwhelming from Dundee’s fellow Championship clubs and % of all the clubs that it wasn’t wanted.“It’s clear from that there isn’t really a problem from most clubs on the U-turn – the majority wanted it with over % voting that way and the Deloitte inquiry said there was no wrongdoing.“With reconstruction talks ending, fans do wonder what John Nelms achieved through the U-turn but I think we are all past it now. I’ve not had anyone on to me about it all, there’s very little online about this week’s vote – I don’t think anyone really cares now.”Rangers vehemently led the call for a vote on an independent inquiry into the SPFL’s conduct during the coronavirus shutdown, as well as Dundee’s actions in changing their vote.That led to Gers fans bombarding online posts from the club and DSA social media, but Ross believes the reaction from fellow Dundee supporters is telling.He added: “Anytime the DSA are posting stuff on social media, we have to go through and delete loads of stuff.“It’s almost amusing now – Dundee fans responding generally laugh at them. title: dundee united ian harkes grandfather coronavirus
story: He could hardly have been further away, but the coronavirus pandemic hit close to home for Dundee United midfielder Ian Harkes.His grandfather, Ron Kunihiro, had been fighting Covid- since early March with Harkes stuck in Dundee unable to catch a flight back to America.Thankfully, now at their family home in Virginia and by his side, Harkes has witnessed the -year-old recover.“I was just happy to get home. My granddad got out of the hospital and he’s been battling Covid,” the -year-old said.“He’s had it for a while. It’s been a long process which started back in the beginning of March when he first started to feel ill.“He went in to the hospital for  days or so. I was still in Dundee so we had to FaceTime or Zoom call the family to keep updated on everything.“Thankfully, we were able to find some flights and get back over.“He’s healthy now which is great. It’s been great to see him recover and nice to be here with the family.“The challenge now is getting back over to Scotland but, thankfully, I’ve got a UK passport so I should be OK!”Harkes travelled back to the states with fiancée and Celtic Women’s player Sarah Teegarden a few weeks back.Their wedding plans are on hold and the country is in disarray but Harkes insists it’s nice to spend precious time with his loved ones.He continued: “She was able to come back as well which is good.“It’s nice to spend time together but all our wedding plans will be pushed back now.“On the mental side being back with them all helps tremendously, missing them throughout the year.“They came over around Christmas time but seeing them again six months later has been big. It always gives me a lt.“It’s a bit dferent here than the UK. Some things don’t seem so shut down but that’s just America right now – we’re not quite sure what’s going on.“It’s quite crazy just now with the amount of cases and, unfortunately, the amount of deaths we’ve had in America.“I think the country’s a little bit all over the place, some places are opening up and some are closed, but right now we’re still in lockdown in Virginia.“All the states are dferent but it’s been OK here.“I’m not sure how long that will be but we need to be safe, especially with having that experience in my family.“I think we’ve all had a little bit of a dferent view towards it but we’ll see how it goes and hope for the best.“We can still exercise and things like that. I’ve had space to go and run and cycle, do some things in the yard and touch a ball every day.“It’s been good to have certain resources back home and to keep doing stuff.”Like most, lockdown has been a test for Harkes’ mentally and physically. For him, it’s a challenge he soon hopes to rise to on the pitch.Harkes added: “It’s definitely been a challenge on both sides but, thankfully, the club provided us with a great fitness programme before we went on furlough to keep us ticking over.“I’ve been active and all of us want to be flying when we finally get the go-ahead to get back to playing.“We’re all trying to push each other and push ourselves.“On the mental side, the way we ended was a little tough because we wanted to play for the fans and finish out the season.“We really felt like we deserved the title and we knew it then but we just wanted to finish off the games and prove it to everyone.“We’ll have that desire to get back on the pitch and play hard when we finally get it going.”The United support have taken to Harkes since he joined the club in January last year, as much for his flowing locks as his skill on the pitch.He is pleased to inform them nothing has changed on the hair front in lockdown but that he might soon be forced to take matters into his own hands.“I’m still going strong but it will be cut before everything gets going again,” Harkes said.“I think it’s getting a bit ridiculous now.“I don’t want to start putting it up in a bun and everything. story: A local authority has received praise for the work it has carried out supporting young people in Aberdeen.Aberdeen City Council has been congratulated by Education Scotland for its efforts during Covid-.More than , Chromebooks and iPads have been provided to families to support home learning, to ensure every child without a device at home can access the support.It also aims to provide connectivity to its most vulnerable families, ensuring they can take part in regular check-ins with teachers.Gayle Gorman, Her Majesty’s chief inspector of education and chief executive of Education Scotland, said: “With the ever-changing situation with Covid-, it is a challenging time for everyone and we recognise the pressure that teachers, local authorities and children are facing during this dficult time.“The work which Aberdeen City Council has been doing is an excellent example of how authorities can adapt to a completely new way of working to ensure that learning continues for children and young people.#I want to thank the council, the teachers and the support staff for demonstrating this commitment to providing the best for our young people.”Councillor John Wheeler, Aberdeen City Council’s education operational delivery convener, added: “We are working hard to ensure that learning can continue at home for all our pupils and our teachers have been exemplary in their dedication and the support they have given at this challenging time.#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: argyll sport decimated amid coronavirus response
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe coronavirus response has forced the cancellation of sporting events up and down the region.Just when the situation will settle down enough to allow sport to re-start is anyone#s guess at this stage, but early casualties have included shinty, football, athletics and a planned youth football trip to Europe.The committee of Mid Argyll Athletic Club took the dficult decision to postpone the Argyll final of Sports Hall Athletics which was due to take place at Atlantis Leisure in Oban this Sunday, March .With more than  young boys and girls qualying for the final from the four local area competitions and the possibility of another -plus family member spectators filling the games hall the organisers felt it was sensible to postpone the event.A statement from the organisers said: #After consultation with the management staff at Atlantis Leisure it was decided it was best to follow the guidance that is currently being issued by the Scottish Government and others to attempt to restrict the spread of the coronavirus.#We will revisit a date for holding the competition once the coronavirus situation is clear andnecessary this may be have to be after the summer school holidays. The boys and girls who qualied from the local area competitions in Lochgilphead, Oban, Tobermory and Campbeltown will be advised of the new Argyll final date and times through their local club or school.#We apologise for any inconvenience and disappointment this postponement may cause to the young athletes and their families.#The annual Crinan Puffer # an .-mile race between Crinan and Ardrishaig # has also been postponed.A fundraiser for Mid Argyll Community Pool organised with the help of Mid Argyll Athletic Club, the run was due to be held on Sunday March .Announcing the postponement, Kirsty Young of Mid Argyll Community Pool said: #In light of current government guidelines to avoid non-essential contact and unnecessary travel we feel that this is the right decision to make.#I will be contacting all stakeholders involved with the organisation and running of the event in the coming days to try and come up with a date to re-schedule the event.#Months of work to raise money for a trip to Holland in April for young Mid Argyll footballers has come to nothing, thanks to coronavirus.Lochgilphead Red Star  players, coaches, parents and supporters were left disappointed when the Amsterdam tournament was cancelled.A committee spokesperson said: #The team are devastated not to be going after nine months of fundraising for the event. We are lucky enough to be getting a full refund from the organisers and at present are awaiting to seethe same will happen regarding the flights.#We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone from the public to businesses who have supported us throughout our fundraising, from attending coffee mornings, donating at bag packs and online donations and our hypnotist night. Your generosity has been overwhelming .#We plan to let the kids of the team decide which charities they would like to donate the funds to once we receive the refund.#After just one week of the  season, shinty#s governing body, the Camanachd Association, made the decision on Friday March  to postpone all matches until further notice.The association also recommended that this should include all training, festivals and other events.In a statement, the Camanachd Association said: #In light of the government restrictions on public gatherings and the resulting pressure on emergency services and healthcare provision, the Camanachd Association has postponed all fixtures under our auspices whilst a further assessment can be made and to reduce any additional pressure our activities may have otherwise had on emergency services.#The wellbeing of the people in our communities is primary in this decision and we hope that this decision removes any expectations or pressures on participating during a time that we can be focused on doing all we can to suppress the spread of the virus.#The recommendation is that shinty clubs should hold any meetings using remote technology such as Skype.The association statement concluded: #We will endeavour to provide due notice to clubs ahead of any future shinty matches so as there is time to restart training.#The Scottish Football Association also decided to suspend all matches in the interests of public health for the and health and safety of players, match officials and staff across the game.Ian Maxwell, SFA chief executive, said: #This is of paramount importance as the country enters the #delay# phase of the coronavirus pandemic.#The decision to suspend or continue training is at each club’s discretion at this time, however clubs must ensure to follow the current medical guidance issued by the government and the health authorities when making this decision.Scottish Rugby decided that with effect from Sunday  March at pm there would be a short period without domestic competition or training up to March .This includes rugby in all domestic league and cup fixtures, training, festivals and other rugby events as well as the FOSROC Super tournament, which come under Scottish Rugby#s jurisdiction.The Scottish Rugby age grade programmehas been cancelled with immediate effect for the remainder of the season.A Scottish Rugby Spokesperson said: #We have taken on board all expert medical advice before now and we are taking a precautionary approach to give time to assess what the impact of coronavirus will be on Scottish society in the coming weeks before deciding on next steps.#
