title: minister last someone calls our churches be opened again
story: Investigation launched after ‘senseless and cruel murder’ of ‘family man’ in his home - PSNI appeal for informationNo injuries sustained after trailer overturns on NI roadNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsPeopleMinister: At last, someone calls for our churches to be opened againA hearty thank you to Billy Kennedy for his opinion piece on Saturday regarding church closures .By Rev ET KirklandTuesday, th May , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th May , : pm""Opening for solitary prayer is not an evangelical practice : Johnston Press‘It is time for all of our churches to reopen’.He has stated exactly what other voices have failed to do. The smock and gown ecclesiastical elites are matched by the silence of evangelical churches and ministers.Letter to the editor : Johnston Press Resell " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...It seems to me that there is no clamour for opening because there is little sense of essentialist public worship.There is no protest because there is no longer any loyalty to the crown rights of the redeemer.Our American cousins for all their faults continue to meet in their buildings and where they are closed, in the open air.Further, what Billy Kennedy calls the diktat has been rigorously opposed by them.Meanwhile here, statism rules. The state is now God. Those who prostrate themselves before the state have seemingly taken over the pulpits. Hence the lackluster response to the lockdown.What we need to learn is who exactly is calling the shots at Stormont and, upon what basis was it decided that numerous centres, such as garden and shopping, can open and the churches remain closed  Opening for solitary prayer is not an evangelical practice.The public professing Church of Christ should hang its collective head in shame at its abject failure.I fear that there is no lobbying because there is little fear of God.Rev ET Kirkland, Free Church Manse, Ballyclare

title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: A total of  of these cases were in the Vale of Glamorgan where a further  people tested positive on Wednesday.In total  people have been tested for the virus in the Vale, of whom . per cent have tested positive.Meanwhile, the virus has claimed  more lives across Wales, meaning  have now passed away with the disease.There were  new cases of covid- reported in Wales, taking the total number of confirmed cases to ,, although the true number of cases is likely to be higher.Dr Robin Howe, Incident Director for the Novel Coronavirusoutbreak response at Public Health Wales, said: ldquoWe offer our condolences to families and friends affected, and we ask those reporting on the situation to respect patient confidentiality.ldquoPublic Health Wales has conducted more than , tests for Novel Coronaviruson more than , iniduals since the start of this outbreak.It comes as a Welsh Government minister said lockdown rules will continue into at least next week.When the UK-wide lockdown rules were announced, prime minister Boris Johnson said they would be reviewed every three weeks.Next Monday, April , marks three weeks since the announcement.But, speaking at a press conference yesterday, the Welsh Government housing and local government minister Julie James said this was too soon to lt the lockdown and the rules would remain in force in Wales into the start of next week - and possibly further.A more formal announcement on the continuation of lockdown guidelines will be given soon."These are extraordinary times, and weve taken these measures because by working together we can slow the speed of the coronavirus," Mrs James said."We will definitely be extending the guidelines, and more formal restrictions will be announced within the next few days. What I do know is that the measures will definitely stay in force after Monday."With the Easter weekend coming up, Mrs James also reiterated the importance of abiding by the rules."There are signs that these measures are having an impact," she said. title: food vouchers sent   parents vale glamorgan
story: Though schools in the Vale have been closed for normal lessons since Monday March , many continued providing free meals.But it was later discovered that only a small faction of these were being claimed.Now the parents of the  Vale pupils in receipt of free school meals have been sent vouchers, which can be used to purchase food from a local supermarket.Arrangements were put in place for Tesco and Asda vouchers to be distributed and it is hoped a similar system can be established with other food outlets, including smaller operators located in the rural Vale.Parents will receive a pound voucher every fortnight, which equates to  school meals worth pound. for each eligible child.Councillor Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Regeneration and Education, said: ldquoI have been immensely proud of the way council staff have responded to such dficult circumstances and there is no better example of that than within our Learning and Skills teams.ldquoIn just two days staff working there have established a completely new system for administering free school meal provision so that no child goes without.ldquoSetting up this voucher system will help ensure a great many more children get the meals they are entitled to as only a small proportion were recently being claimed from schools.ldquoThe need to develop this system so quickly inevitably title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cafe offers delivery service help need
story: Staff at the Marie Curie Hospice in Penarth" Café offers delivery service to help those in needCharlotte Court , co-owner of Willmore#s , delivers food parcels ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtto Llandough lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA LOCAL cafeacute has started a regular food delivery service to support frontline staff and their patients who are suffering from Covid- at Llandough Hospital.The co-owners of Willmorersquos  on Stanwell Road, Matthew Holland and Charlotte Court, have delivered over  meals to frontline facilities in Penarth since the beginning of the pandemic, including the Marie Curie Hospice on Bridgeman Road.Now the pair have plans to extend their operations.They have raised over pound for the charitable cause, which includes money collected in a fundraiser by the community support group, Helping Hands Penarth.ldquoWe closed the shop three weeks ago and used all the leftover stock to do the first delivery to the hospital, explained Matthew.ldquoWersquove all got to be doing something and we felt like we had to utilize the shop and give something back to the guys that are putting their lives at risk.ldquoPenarth is a really small town and yoursquove just got to try and support each other as much as possible.ldquoI think yoursquove got to step up and do as much as you can,you can. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. It was so emotional being able to see the nurses on the Covid ward.ldquoFor me and Charlotte it was very humbling because those guys are putting their lives at risk and theyrsquore asking for stuff for patients, not for themselves.ldquoWe were quite tearful because we didnrsquot want to leave them there ndash but theyrsquore doing it day in-day out without batting an eyelid. Amazing people.Alongside their charitable work, Matthew and Charlotte have adapted to the challenging economic climate by introducing a delivery service for their customers.The pair have been working without the support of their staff who they had to furlough after the government closed all non-essential shops.ldquoWersquove started doing take-out because we canrsquot afford to do nothing for three months. Wersquoll lose the shop, said Matthew.ldquoWersquoll continue to do these drop offs for the hospital as long as people fund it, and wersquoll continue to do our take-out service.ldquoBecause for shops and restaurants I think its going to be long term.ldquoWe might be in this for six months before we can open to the public.ldquoAs long as we get the support and people keep shopping locally, then yes we can get through it.ldquoRunning a business is a constant challenge and you donrsquot ever stop having to adapt. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Irsquove also recorded online conversations with council leaders and police, and these are available to view on my page at any time. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... local residents to exercise,The change follows the small adjustments to coronavirus restrictions recently announced by Welsh Government.Porthkerry, Cosmeston, and other parks were be available for exercise only to those living locally from Saturday.But, leisure activities such as sunbathing, picnicking, barbecues and social gathering remain prohibited as does the use of any play equipment.More NewsVandals cause fire damage at Dinas Powys Cricket ClubMiss Vale of Glamorgan  supports NHS during coronavirus pandemicPenarth Cemetery reopens to public on trial basisFacilities within the locations such as public toilets and other amenities will remain closed and it is recommended visitors bring hand sanitiser for personal use.Those living outside the immediate area should not be using these spaces as, though exercise is now permitted more than once a day, it should start and end at home and not involve travelling a signicant distance.All parking facilities within the parks will remain closed to the public.When exercising, it is vital residents continue to adhere to social distancing guidance by staying at least two metres from anyone not in their household.Signs informing people of the new regulations will be installed in the coming days and council enforcement officers will be making regular visits to parks to ensure everyone is staying safe.All play areas will remain closed for safety reasons, as the coronavirus can remain active on hard surfaces for  hours.Vale council leader, Cllr Neil Moore said: ldquoThe council has been regularly reviewing the services that reopen from Tuesday, May , but by appointment only.The booking system is to help comply with social distancing regulations, protecting residents and staff.Residents will be able to book an appointment from am on Thursday, May  via the Vale councilrsquos website.There will be  slots released for the next fortnight of bookings, beginning May  -  slots at Atlantic Trading Estate and  for Llandow.Any resident undertaking a journey to a HWRC within the Vale must comply with the current Government guidance and adhere to the social distancing measures that are in place to ensure safe operation and use of the centres.To begin with, only cars will be permitted access to the HWRC on Atlantic Trading Estate, Barry, and at Llandow.It will not be possible to provide access or appointment for trailers or vans at this time.Due to current demand, initially the council will be only be issuing one appointment slot per household, per month until further notice.Residents are asked to only make a bookingit is absolutely necessary, due to the sitesrsquo reduced capacity, and to arrive no earlier than five minutes before their allocated time to avoid any unnecessary queuing.The guidelines state that before visiting, residents must sort their waste or recycling appropriately to minimise the time at the site and residents must provide proof of residency eg driving licence or utility bill and display this in their windscreen while waiting to enter the site.Residents must follow on-site safety signs and guidance and residents should only exit their car when advised to do so by a member of site staff.Staff will be unable to provide assistance with lting or sorting so it is important to ensure all waste and recycling is manageable.Residents are also reminded thatthey do not respect social distancing or are abusive to staff they will be asked to leave site.It is important to remember that fly-tipping is a crime and leaving items outside the gates of a HWRC, on the street or in parks, woodlands and fields may result in a fixed penalty notice of up to pound being issued or even prosecution.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank residents for the assistance they have provided by storing items they wish to dispose of until now.ldquoUnfortunately, the period during which our household waste recycling centres were closed means there is now a backlog to clear, which is why we need a strict booking system until demand s to normal.ldquoWe appreciate this may cause some inconvenience but would ask residents for their patience at this time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey since the coronavirus lockdown has taken to the streets to capture le on the inside.Mum-of-one, Katrina Dimech is normally a photographer and videographer and teacher at Shutter Hire Kids Photography Club, but instead she decided to use her skills to raise money for the charity - Annarsquos Rescue Centre, in Cardf, from where she got her cat, Rocky.Miss Dimech, , of Penarth, took portraits of families stood on their doorsteps locally as a personal project, on Friday May .And she hopes to stage an exhibition when conditions allow.She said: ldquoI had lost all motivation.ldquoMy camera had been sitting in a bag unused for eight weeks and I was getting far too used to sitting in my pyjamas all day.ldquoThe aim was to capture this strange moment in history and to be able to do what I love - get out and take photographs while following government guidelines.ldquoI havenrsquot been able to work since March and photography is a huge part of my lestyle and happiness.ldquoI have been able to create beautul memories for these families.ldquoBack in March our family adopted a beautul family cat, Rocky, from Annarsquos Rescue Centre in Rumney, she said. ldquoWe were amazed to discover how much work this charity was doing in rescuing, rehabilitating, caring for, and rehoming cats and kittens.ldquoI realised that I could use this opportunity to raise some money for the charity by combining my doorstep photography project as a fundraiser."Donations were not compulsory.ldquoDuring lockdown this money is very much needed to feed the surplus cats that currently canrsquot be rehomed due to vets not neutering at this time, but also to help towards any upkeep or vets bills.ldquoMyself and my partner visited  homes beginning at am and finishing at :pm.ldquoWe met some amazing families and thoroughly enjoyed our day out.ldquoWe have plans to attempt one more session in Dinas Powys, Sully, and Barry.She said: ldquoWhen I started the project I was worried that I wouldnrsquot find much to photograph and that it would be dficult to find inspiration on someonersquos doorstop.ldquoI was wrong.ldquoEach family has a very dferent dynamic and portrait photography is all about allowing dferent personalities shine through.ldquoThe images were intended to be natural, raw, and a reflection of the times and I feel that I have achieved that outcome with the help of those who took part.Miss Dimech and her partner allowed  minutes for each household.ldquoIt was amazing to meet so many new faces and to catch up with some of my previous clients," she said. ldquoEach household was extremely thankful and it was a blessing to have that social interaction that most of us have all been craving.ldquoWorking with people is what I do best.ldquoI am a chatterbox who thrives on social interaction.ldquoEach family had a dferent story to tell, some were still working, furloughed, bored or enjoying lockdown.ldquoI met animals, children, grandparents, parents, it was a great mix.ldquoMeeting new people and wielding a camera just makes my heart sing."I came home after a long day just bursting with excitement to start editing.ldquoOnce this is all over and the pandemic is just a memory I have plans to use these images as part of a photography exhibition and once donations have stopped coming in I have plans to visit the cattery to hand over cat food and title: apprentices losing work learning opportunities amid covid    poll
story: The pandemic is having a signicant effect on apprenticeships, according to a Sutton Trust report, which warns that a fall in apprenticeship starts is likely to be exacerbated by the crisis.A YouGov poll of  employers suggests that more than three in fivesay their apprentices have lost out on learning or work experience as a result of the Covid- pandemic.Respondents said more than a thirdhave been furloughed, around one in thirteenhave been made redundant and % have had their off-the-job learning suspended.Nearly one in fouremployers who offered apprenticeships said their apprenticesrsquo learning provider had closed and % said their provider was unable to continue provision online.The education charity warns that there will be fewer apprenticeship vacancies available for young people as firms are likely to focus on recovering from the coronavirus crisis.The poll has been released alongside separate research from the Sutton Trust on degree apprenticeships ndash which combine academic learning and on-the-job training.Well-off, older students have largely benefited from the growth in degree-level apprenticeships, according to the report, which shows more than half of degree apprenticeships at university are taken up by people aged  or over.Senior leadership courses ndash equivalent to a Master of Business Administrationqualication ndash have expanded signicantly in recent years.But the proportion of young apprentices from deprived communities taking degree-level apprenticeships up has fallen from % in - to % in -.In that same time, the proportion of degree level apprentices older than  from the most advantaged areas has more than doubled ndash from % to %.The charity is calling for apprenticeship levy funding to be spent on providing new opportunities for young people, rather than on subsidising senior executives taking MBA-style qualications.The report also recommends that apprentices should be allowed to continue training where possible, even when on furlough orredeployed within a firm.Sir Peter Lampl, founder and chairman of the Sutton Trust, said: ldquoThe coronavirus crisis has already had a serious impact on apprentices, with % being made redundant or furloughed, or unable to access their learning.ldquoThe priority for current apprentices should be to continue their training where possible and the Government must do more to support training providers.ldquoIn the long-term, apprenticeships have a crucial role to deliver on the Governmentrsquos social mobility agenda, which will be especially important as we come out of the pandemic.Andrew Harden, head of further education at the University and College Union , said: ldquoThe pandemic is having a major impact on apprenticeships with a majority missing out on work or their learning.ldquoThe Government must step in and guarantee that apprentices donrsquot lose out from this crisis.Toby Perkins, Labourrsquos shadow apprenticeships minister, said: ldquoApprenticeships are crucial as a tool for social mobility and in our countryrsquos fight against the productivity deficit that we have compared to other nations.ldquoThis research demonstrates how precarious the apprenticeship sector is and the anticipated fall in new starts is deeply concerning.ldquoTo address Britainrsquos productivity crisis, the Government needs a joined up approach to skills and apprenticeships in order to support the aspirations of the younger generation.YouGov surveyed  senior HR decision makers of which  were employing apprentices in March . title: inflation plunges near four year low april
story: The Office for National Statisticssaid the rate of the Consumer Price Indexfell more than expected to .% in April ndash the lowest level since August  and down sharply on the .% recorded in March.Most economists expected inflation to fall to .%. vw,vw,px, px"CPI is now far wide of the Bank of Englandrsquos % target, while it is set to drop sharply lower still, with some economists bracing for a near-zero headline rate of inflation by the summer.The ONS said average petrol prices dropped by .p a litre between March and April ndash the biggest fall since unleaded petrol records began in  ndash amid the global oil price rout.Energy prices also pushed inflation lower as regulator Ofgem reduced its default tarf cap.Jonathan Athow, deputy national statistician for economic statistics at the ONS, said: ldquoWhile the coronavirus limited the availability of some goods and services, its effect on prices was more muted.ldquoFalling petrol and diesel prices, combined with changes to the domestic energy price cap were the main reasons for lower inflation in April.The consumer price inflation including owner occupiersrsquo costs-month rate was .% in April, down from .% in March  https:t.co vcWHjKyXT pic mdEUtkQmdash Office for National Statistics May , ldquoGames, toys and hobbies saw rising prices, perhaps as people occupied their time at home.ldquoFood prices grew no more quickly than other goods and services, though fresh vegetables did see stronger rises.The ONS said the Ofgem cap changes last month meant that gas prices fell .% between March and April, while the cost of electricity edged .% higher, compared with hikes of .% and .% respectively a year ago.The figures showed some effects of the coronavirus crisis, with prices of fresh vegetables rising month-on-month in April, possibly as retailers switched to British-grown produce amid the pandemic, according to the ONS.Long-le products ndash such as cook-in sauce and frozen fish ndash also saw price hikes last month as consumers stocked up to weather le in lockdown.But the ONS cautioned over the challenges of collecting the inflation data, with  goods or services unavailable in April as panic buying and stockbuilding left some supermarket shelves bare across the UK.The data also showed the Retail Price Index , a separate measure of inflation, was .% in April, down from .% in March.The Consumer Price Index including owner-occupiersrsquo housing costsndash the ONSrsquos preferred measure of inflation ndash was .% last month, down from .% in March.Samuel Tombs, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said inflation had taken a ldquobig leap towards zero by the summer as he said retailers were planning ldquofurther large price cuts.He predicted inflation would recover next year but was likely to remain below % for much of .ldquoThe inflation outlook, then, supports theMonetary Policy Committee doing more to stimulate the economy at its next meeting in title: serco apologises sharing email addresses contact tracing recruits
story: The company is helping to sign up people to support efforts to track and trace cases of Covid- to help reduce the spread of the disease in the UK.The Government has promised to recruit , contact tracers to manually gather information about the places infected people have visited and other iniduals they have been in contact with to get a detailed picture of who might be at risk of infection.The error at Serco saw  addresses being included in a CCsection of an email rather than BCC , meaning they were visible to recipients.It is understood that all the affected recruits had given the company permission to use their personal email addresses.No information other than the email addresses was shared.Serco is not intending to noty the Information Commissionerrsquos Officefollowing the error and is not aware of a complaint being made.A spokesman for the company said: ldquoAn email was sent to new recruits who had given us their permission to use their personal email addresses.ldquoIn error, email addresses were visible to other recipients. We have apologised and reviewed our processes to make sure that this does not happen again.In February Serco said it had grown annual revenues for the first time since  afterwinning major contracts, including a pound. billion deal to supply asylum accommodation and one worth pound million to provide prisoner escorts and custody services in the UK.It came after the company and fellow outsourcer GS found themselves at the centre of a public and political storm in  when it emerged that the pair had been overcharging the Government for electronically monitoring people who were either dead or in jail, or had left the country.The two businesses were stripped of their responsibility for tagging criminals in the UK later that year.It led to a pound. million settlement by Serco with the Serious Fraud Office, on top of a pound million fine from the Ministry of Justice in December ..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Serco apologises for sharing email addresses of contact-tracing recruits article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: council welcomes funding
story: Woman pushed into boot of car during ‘attempted abduction’Ambulance crews deal with two car crash on Armagh roadNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsCouncil welcomes fundingThe Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council has welcomed the Executive’s COVID- emergency funding for local councils.By The NewsroomTuesday, th May , : pm""This morningCommunities Minister, Deirdre Hargey, informed the Assembly that the Executive had agreed to provide a total of £. million to NorthernIreland’s  councils by way of an “immediate intervention”.Speaking after the announcement was made, ABC Lord Mayor, Councillor Mealla Campbell said: “As a Council it is our priority during this crisis to protect and ensure the delivery of our basic services but like many other councils at this time, the future of these essential services such as bin collections, burials and street cleansing are threatened by loss of income“I therefore welcome this announcement of funding, which will provide some interim assistance from now until the end of June.”Editorial Image. : Other rd PartyCommunities Minister, Deirdre Hargey MLA said: “Despite the current COVID- pandemic, councils continue to play an essential role in deliveringpublic services, such as waste collection and disposal, community support, and provision of registration and cemeteryservices.“The restrictions that have been introduced, with the clear purpose of protecting le and ensuring out health service has not been overwhelmed, have created a severe financial challenge for our  councils as they have lost practically all of their self-generated income through the closure of council facilities.“This funding will help assist councils with their cash flow and support them in the delivery of the vital services they are providing to the community at this time.“It will also help ensure that they are ready to play their key role in our post-pandemic recovery and limit the financial impact on ratepayers going forward.”While the additional funding is welcomed, Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s Lord Mayor said more will need to be done to ensure council’s can help communities to recover.“It is a first step but it is clear that further investment in local government will be required to ensure that Council are not only in a position to provide continuity of service to our ratepayers but that we are able to help our communities recover,” said the Lord Mayor.“The executive must look at longer term investment to support the financial resilience of our councils so that we are resourced to deliver on strategies for bespoke economic recovery and community support.“Councils will be in the frontline of transformation post COVID- and it is a priority that we are equipped to deal with the signicant body of work ahead.“Meanwhile a spokesperson for Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council said Council will continue to ensure vital public services are protected.“Council welcomes the announcement by Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey, and will continue to work with the Minister, and colleagues across councils, to make the case for support of local government to ensure vital public services are protected,” said the spokesperson.Adam Morton , Local Democracy Reporting Service""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" just been issued from the four UK Chief Medical Officers on an update to coronavirus symptoms. “From today, all iniduals should self-isolatethey develop a new continuous cough or fever or anosmia. “Anosmia is the loss or a change in your normal sense of smell. It can also affect your sense of taste as the two are closely linked. “We have been closely monitoring the emerging data and evidence on COVID- and after thorough consideration, we are now confident enough to recommend this new measure. “The inidual’s household should also self-isolate for  days as per the current guidelines and the inidual should stay at home for seven days, or longerthey still have symptoms other than cough or loss of sense of smell or taste, they said. The statement is signed by Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, Chief Medical Officer for Northern Ireland, Dr Michael McBride, Chief Medical Officer for Scotland, Dr Gregor Smith and Chief Medical Officer for England, Professor Chris Whitty. Changes for the symptomatic inidual and their household: Iniduals will need to self-isolate immediatelythey develop a new continuous cough OR fever OR as of today, a loss or changed sense of normal smell or taste .
